School meals are seen as a way to encourage children to try new foods and eat healthily, with school meals now adhering to strict nutritional guidelines. The survey, conducted online, included parents with children aged 4-17 and found that about 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, compared to 46% in Scotland.

Alvaro Morata, 23, currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His transfer included a buy-back option for Real Madrid, with a fee up to 30 million euros (£23m). Morata, previously linked to Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three goals for Spain in the tournament. At Juventus, he scored 27 goals over two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in two Champions League finals. He started his career at Real Madrid, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the team.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and made 51 appearances before being released in May. The 30-year-old had previously spent four seasons at Forest and also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. As part of the deal, around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, and Tesco will loan the new business approximately £80m. Fresh & Easy, which has operated 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007, has consistently lost money. Tesco will incur a cost of £150m to dispose of the brand, but part of this is a loan that may be repaid. Additionally, Tesco has the option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable under Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm run by billionaire Ron Burkle. Tesco recently reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

The passage describes how an individual initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and, after briefly considering representing France, is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant reduction in glacier coverage in the French Alps from the late 1960s/early 1970s to the late 2000s, with a decrease from 375 sq km to about 275 sq km. This research, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie. They used map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess around 600 glaciers. The study found that glacier retreat is more pronounced in the southern Alps compared to the northern Alps, likely due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also seen a slight reduction in size. Similar trends of glacier retreat have been observed in other parts of the Alps, including Switzerland.

The Scots women's football team has won all five of their qualifiers and is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their place in the finals. Forward Evans, who has experienced past play-off disappointments, emphasizes the importance of this opportunity. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for determining the group leader. Evans, along with other players, brings international experience from top leagues, which she believes benefits the national team. She recently celebrated winning the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and highlights the positive impact of playing abroad on the team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England following a harassment complaint from a woman in south London, alleging a two-year period of harassment. Campbell, who was released on bail, stated the issue involved non-threatening tweets and accused the media of encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed an investigation into the online harassment allegation. Campbell, who launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011, announced he would be posting less frequently due to circumstances beyond his control. He emphasized that the tweets in question remain publicly visible and are not threatening.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to promote an animal-friendly image. The Jolly Fisherman, created in 1908 to attract tourists, is seen by Peta as symbolizing animal cruelty. Dawn Carr from Peta argues that the current mascot evokes harmful fishing practices and suggests the change would help rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, believes the Jolly Fisherman is a beloved and positive symbol for the town and doubts there will be much support for the change. He acknowledges the importance of addressing animal cruelty but feels the current mascot does not convey such a message.

Scotland secured a dominant victory over Georgia, despite an early try from Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, leading 31-11 at halftime. Hamish Watson extended the lead after the break. Georgia's scrum earned them a second try, but Scotland's Stuart Hogg and Ali Price added further tries, sealing a comprehensive win. Scotland's head coach Vern Cotter praised the team's first-half performance and their pragmatic approach in the second half. The final score reflected Scotland's control over possession and territory throughout the match.

Widnes led 14-6 at half-time with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Castleford's Paddy Flynn responded. Flynn scored again early in the second half, but further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor extended Widnes' lead to 38-12. Despite a late surge from Castleford with tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn completing his hat-trick, Widnes secured the win. The victory moved Widnes to seventh place, just one point behind sixth-placed Castleford.

Fawzi al-Odah, detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 on suspicion of al-Qaeda and Taliban links, was released after a US review panel deemed him not a "continuing significant threat." He had contested his detention in the US Supreme Court. Al-Odah, who denies the charges, was flown back to Kuwait, where he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center. His release, advocated by the Kuwaiti government, reduces the Guantanamo inmate count to 148. This follows President Obama's ongoing efforts to close the facility, which was established after the 9/11 attacks.

Thousands attended the early morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. Anzac Day was first commemorated in London in 1916, a year after the Gallipoli landings. The day has since become significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, honoring their countrymen's sacrifices in all wars. Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the dawn service, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the heroism of the Anzac troops. Veterans' associations, service personnel, and their families participated in the parade, with crowds, including ex-pats, watching the ceremony. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the war's bloodiest, aiming to force the Ottoman empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined Premiership Well in July and is set to debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals at Dundee and has mostly been a substitute this term. Clarkson feels fit and ready, having maintained his match fitness by playing for the U20s and training hard. He has nearly 400 senior club appearances and has been capped twice for Scotland. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, aim to climb the table with Clarkson's help.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were initial concerns about the continuation of the workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, closed in 2004, remains unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office assured that current pension arrangements would continue. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process both chicken and turkeys.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with a new vessel. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July to gather feedback and acknowledged the project's disappointing start. Since its launch on 14 May, the ferry has experienced breakdowns, grounding, and suspension due to training issues, causing damage to cars. Local businesses, suffering from trade losses, sought compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation was under discussion and described the problems as typical for a prototype, noting that electrical issues had been fixed and ramp extensions were being made to prevent vehicle damage. Grounding issues were attributed to seamanship and had been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that Britain may need to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal. Fishing communities, which largely supported Brexit, risk being sidelined in negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK, and Brexit is seen as a chance to regain control over UK waters. However, the House of Lords report warns of risks, noting that UK fishing is a small part of the economy and relies heavily on exports to the EU. Continued market access may require trade-offs, such as allowing EU access to UK waters. The report suggests retaining some CFP elements and stresses the need for scientific advice and international cooperation. There are concerns about potential fragmentation of fisheries management within the UK. Despite these challenges, some in the industry are optimistic about post-Brexit opportunities. The government aims to balance trade freedom with sustainable fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing indecent images of young boys between April 2004 and February 2014. He was subjected to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special programme for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland (GTC Scotland) hearing, he was removed from the teaching register. The hearing concluded that Geaney's actions were incompatible with being a registered teacher, noting a pattern of behavior over a long period and a high likelihood of recurrence. Geaney, who was 69 at sentencing, was not present at the hearing and is prohibited from reapplying for registration for two years.

Firefighters responded to a fire on Duncan Street on 2 March, which disrupted train services and travel. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to the fire. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, was generally compliant with fire safety laws, according to the fire service. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year and had raised concerns about potential fire impacts. The EA, after joint visits with GMFRS, decided to revoke the company's environmental permit effective 7 August, pending any appeal. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is striving to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline due to attacks on shipments. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where many civilians have been killed. Al-Mekdad denied targeting civilians and accused the US of supporting terrorists. Conflicting reports emerged about rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, with state media denying it and activist groups claiming control. Syria has declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but only 4% has been removed. The US and Russia have expressed concerns about delays, and the OPCW acknowledged security issues are slowing the process. Al-Mekdad affirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

England won the match at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series against Pakistan. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his scores of 254 and an unbeaten 71, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's improvement after self-reflection. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series. Former players Geoffrey Boycott and Michael Vaughan commented on England's dominance and Pakistan's lack of confidence. Pakistan will play a tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care and address unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. Her review will consider factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The review seeks to ensure that those responsible for services understand the realities of residential care and take necessary actions to improve it. However, Mario Kreft from Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment that no care home providers are included on the main advisory panel, which he believes limits the opportunity for effective partnership and sector engagement.

Former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Pittodrie after serving as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One for the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Sheerin was chosen by boss Derek McInnes following a thorough selection process. Despite Arbroath's desire to keep Sheerin, their chairman John Christison understood his wish to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for several Scottish clubs and in Sweden, earning a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis emphasizes the need for a manager who can prevent relegation, noting the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if relegated. Swansea, promoted in 2011, gained a reputation for exciting football but have struggled since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements have diluted the "Swansea Way." Despite this, he feels the current squad can avoid relegation and stresses the importance of staying up for the club and the community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, facing criticism from the scientific community. Known for his lack of modesty and wealth, Venter's work significantly accelerated human genomics. After publishing the human genome, he focused on creating synthetic life, resulting in the organism Synthia. Venter's journey began with a troubled youth and a transformative experience in Vietnam, leading him to excel in medical research. He pioneered rapid gene sequencing techniques and founded The Institute for Genomic Research after leaving the NIH. In 1998, he launched Celera Genomics to decode the human genome, challenging traditional scientific norms. Despite controversy, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue independent research, including the creation of synthetic life and oceanic genetic exploration. His synthetic life project aims to revolutionize industries and address environmental issues.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. A study by the Boston Consulting Group highlights that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships in England are at level three (A-level equivalent), and only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. The report criticizes the complex vocational system in England, which has 18,000 qualifications versus Germany's 330, and notes that most apprenticeships are below level three and aimed at those over 25. It calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a focus on level three and four courses, and suggests that only 10% should be two-year level two courses. The Department for Education states that reforms are underway to improve standards, while the Association of Colleges emphasizes the need for high-quality facilities and expert teaching staff. The report underscores the importance of apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness.

The Briton won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. She can secure her 17th title in the upcoming road race. At 37, she aims for more Paralympic success in Rio de Janeiro next year. As Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, she has 22 medals: 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze, in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 London Games and has 21 world titles in both sports. She started her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference Premier due to financial troubles, despite a last-day effort to avoid relegation. Chester has been reinstated in their place. The club's debt to football creditors totaled £148,000, and despite multiple deadline extensions, they failed to meet the payment requirements. New owner Tommy Agombar could not resolve the issues in time. The club's financial decline began after their relegation from the Football League in 2012, worsened by decreasing attendance. Efforts by fans and the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to save the club were unsuccessful.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, retired from international football at age 30 after earning 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. He expressed well wishes to Sam Allardyce and the England team for the future.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including a notable recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director roles and professorships at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. He was remembered fondly by colleagues for his generosity, academic brilliance, and significant contributions to historically informed music. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, was removed from mainstream schooling by his parents in June due to his inability to cope. They requested a place for him at a special school but were informed in September that all such schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no available timeframe for placement. The boy's mother expressed concerns about his isolation and the overcapacity issue of special schools. Recently, they were informed that an extra classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, potentially allowing their son to start soon. The Education Authority, while unable to comment on individual cases, stated they are reviewing the need for special school places to ensure availability near children's residences, with efforts ongoing to improve placements from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with fixture priority if they stay in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on 9 May. Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements, and the WRU is aware of this. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which conflicts with Football League rules. Newport County is currently fighting to avoid relegation from League Two, with their survival dependent on upcoming match results. Relegation would be a significant setback for the club and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the experiences of a man who survived the civil war in Sierra Leone and later contributed to combating the Ebola crisis. Kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels, he endured brutal conditions and was forced into violence. After escaping to Freetown, he struggled but eventually found hope through a preacher, Richard Cole, who encouraged him to rebuild his life and help others. During the Ebola outbreak in 2014, he and his team educated over 10,000 people, provided food to 11,000, and established an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives. He now focuses on investing in young people to build a better future.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised funds in a month to prevent the auction of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, which were at risk due to a pottery firm's pension debt. The collection will remain at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after being gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum by the Art Fund. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited the pension debt after Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009, leading to its own administration in 2010. The collection was deemed important for Staffordshire and Britain's cultural heritage, and its preservation was celebrated by campaign participants.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town FC are still pending. The Sun reported that Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league footballer, will become a club director. Billericay Town FC, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie following a corner. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made several crucial saves, including a notable one from George Elokobi just before halftime. Blackpool missed a key chance to win the game when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. Colchester ended the match with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as part of a "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will feature a petal-shaped glass structure at the center of a £1bn development including a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could start in 2018, pending planning permission. The 300-acre site, sold to developers in 2016, originally housed a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired power station capable of powering one million homes. The 198-meter-high chimney, a significant landmark, will be preserved as a key feature of the new development.

The passage details the performance of British cyclists at the Hong Kong championships. Mark Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham expressed satisfaction with his medal, while Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised his strategic race execution. In the men's team pursuit, GB lost the bronze to Italy, and Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final. The women's team pursuit squad, including Elinor Barker, finished fifth, with Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighting the team's potential. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but remains scheduled for two more events. Marchant expressed disappointment but acknowledged the focus on long-term preparation for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will make a brief return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy, who reappeared after leaving in 2010, revealed her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in emotional scenes. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, expressed that reuniting the Mitchell family for Peggy's farewell felt right, given his close friendship with Barbara. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the significance of Grant's return, noting it as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden's talents.

Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession as Spurs underperformed at Anfield. Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and readiness to compete for the Premier League title, noting their poor away record against top-six teams. He expressed concern about Chelsea potentially extending their lead. Danny Murphy highlighted Spurs' defensive disarray and inconsistency away from home, suggesting they should have maintained their usual defensive strategy against top teams.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had been in power since 1999. The PDP also lost the presidential election last month, with Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP's decline was evident in key northern states and areas affected by Boko Haram, although it retained control of Rivers State. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the latter performing well only in the south-east and Niger Delta. Despite the APC's success, it failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, posing a challenge for Buhari. The elections were marred by violence, particularly in southern states, but were generally more peaceful than previous years. The PDP, having faced defections and corruption allegations, will need to rebuild under new leadership.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to access online information from signs and posters at the site, including videos and band interviews, on their phones and tablets. The festival, held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, features acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that the augmented reality experience enhances enjoyment for attendees and allows global interaction with the festival. The app will provide updated information, interviews, ticket purchasing, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially removing Park View Educational Trust from running them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless issues were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported feeling undermined by parents and nearly quitting. Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School, placed in special measures, to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about Park View and Nansen Primary, criticizing the trust for failing to promote pupils' development and setting a deadline for the trust to respond. Park View School plans to challenge the Ofsted report legally. Lord Nash also warned Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock to address breaches or face funding termination. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw reported a culture of fear and an organized campaign to impose a narrow ideology in Birmingham schools. Parents criticized Ofsted's findings, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing their own agendas.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court argued that eye specialist Honey Rose's conduct was so substandard it was "criminal." Ms. Rose, who denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter, allegedly failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. This failure, according to the prosecution, led to a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, increased pressure in his skull, and ultimately his death. The prosecution claims Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had performed her duties properly. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and filming it, then sending an explicit clip to her sister. He was also convicted of making the woman's sister and father view sexual images and behaving abusively. Despite denying the charges, he was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court and the case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was assessed as a moderate risk for re-offending. The judge emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's condemnation of his actions.

Ireland scored 165-5 in their T20 match against Afghanistan in Greater Noida, with notable contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 not out), and William Porterfield (39). Despite this, Afghanistan chased down the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). The teams will face each other again on Friday. Ireland's innings suffered an early setback with Paul Stirling's dismissal for a duck, but Thompson and Porterfield stabilized the innings. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only bowler with more than one wicket. Captain Porterfield acknowledged that Ireland fell short of their target and didn't execute well with the ball. Additionally, Ireland missed paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem, but he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs starting on 15 March.

Barcelona insists they committed no offence in Neymar's transfer, despite paying £48.6m to Santos and £34m to his parents. Including all fees and a recent tax payment, Neymar's total cost to the club is £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid related accusations. Initially, Barcelona claimed Neymar cost £48.6m, but further contracts suggest a higher amount. A Spanish judge found enough evidence to continue investigating. Barcelona denies any tax crime and made an additional tax payment of 13.55m euros to protect its reputation. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three Champions League goals this season.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, alleged to have confessed to the murders. The UK police will now compile a report and update the victims' families. The suspects face charges of conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, potentially leading to the death penalty. Concerns have been raised about the investigation's integrity, particularly regarding DNA verification and suspect treatment. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and head injuries, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA evidence links the suspects to the crime.

The Scots women's football team has won all five of their qualifiers and is set to host Iceland, knowing a victory would nearly secure their place in the finals. Forward Evans, who has experienced past play-off losses, emphasizes the importance of this opportunity. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for determining the group leader. Evans, along with other players, highlights the emotional significance of reaching the finals and the advantage of having a strong fan presence. The team benefits from having players in top international leagues, which enhances their skills and competitiveness. Evans, who recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, notes the positive impact of international experience on the national team.

The passage discusses the security measures Apple has implemented following the theft of intimate celebrity photos from iCloud using third-party software. Apple has introduced an optional two-step verification process that requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device, in addition to the username and password, to access iCloud. This aims to prevent unauthorized access, although it remains an opt-in feature. Experts suggest making it the default setting. The two-step verification now also covers Apple's backup service, which was previously vulnerable. Elcomsoft's software, used in the hacks, can no longer access iCloud data due to these changes. Despite improvements, concerns remain about the recovery key's security and usability. Apple plans to encourage stronger security practices among users.

In the recent election, UKIP, which won, spent £2,956,737, while the Tories spent £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The campaign period was from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, Labour's 26p, the Conservatives' 79p, and the Lib Dems' £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the top six parties spent a total of £9,347,087. All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival and may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, is moving to the Gulls pending international clearance, having previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite being treated by veterinary staff, he was pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) noted that such incidents are rare and can occur in healthy horses across all sports. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day of the race. He had a history of success, including winning the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the "horse of a lifetime." The BHA and BBC correspondent Cornelius Lysaght emphasized that Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues, although he had been treated for overheating in the past. The report concludes that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage.

The passage describes the emotional farewell speeches of several veteran MSPs, including Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie, as they step down ahead of the May 5 election. Alex Salmond, former First Minister, emphasized Scotland's unity and the need for greater parliamentary responsibility, while also humorously acknowledging the day's competing events. Duncan McNeil highlighted the importance of accountability and learning from Westminster's committee system. Annabel Goldie humorously reflected on her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick expressed gratitude for their contributions, noting their distinguished service to the parliament and Scotland.

The passage discusses the casting and release details of a live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." The star will play Mrs. Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The film is set to release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, with filming starting at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans died, at a meeting with victims' relatives. Last year, new inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. Evidence files on 23 suspects were referred to the CPS, with 15 related to the disaster's causes and 8 to police conduct afterward. Relatives will be informed of the decisions in a private meeting. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, expressed hope for closure and emphasized the families' desire for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with reports of the facility being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the hard work of staff to prevent contraband but admits more needs to be done, as directed by the Justice Secretary. A local resident has observed packages being thrown over the wall multiple times recently and expressed concerns about safety. Despite claims from a former inmate about drones delivering contraband, the Ministry of Justice states there is no evidence of drone activity at Chelmsford. New laws have been introduced to penalize those who smuggle packages into prisons with up to two years of imprisonment.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. He admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse in court, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The incident occurred as Mrs. Blackburn was helping a woman and her child cross the road. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast next year due to her veterinary medicine studies, which include exams in May. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, is optimistic about her future in athletics, including potential participation in the World Indoor Championships in March and future Olympics. She recently set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after a Christmas party. A search began in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed his case, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he vanished. The footage shows Deely talking to an unidentified man in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, and later being followed by the same man on Haddington Road. Gardaí have appealed for this man to come forward, but he remains unidentified.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after a long injury hiatus, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in a comeback match at a Grand Slam, his first since the 2014 Australian Open. Del Potro, who has undergone three wrist surgeries, expressed joy at his victory and return to tennis. In the same tournament, Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match, winning 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 to advance to the third round, where he will face Feliciano Lopez. Lopez also made a comeback from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini. Additionally, Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga secured straightforward wins in their respective matches.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf but avoided it by apologizing. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup but re-entered after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, leading to Equatorial Guinea stepping in as hosts. Tunisia's dispute with Caf arose from a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a threat of disqualification unless they apologized. After a meeting with Caf officials, Tunisia resolved the issue and confirmed their participation in the 2017 tournament. Tunisia will compete in Group A, and Morocco in Group F, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

The passage details the decline and hopeful resurgence of the McLaren F1 team, once a dominant force with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles. The team's downturn began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, despite having a strong engine. Currently, the car's performance has improved, but the Honda power-unit remains problematic. Historically, McLaren achieved significant success with Honda in the late 1980s and with Mercedes in the late 1990s. The team faced scandals in 2007 and 2009, impacting their reputation. Ron Dennis, who has led the team through various eras, believes McLaren will soon break Mercedes' dominance and return to winning championships. Fernando Alonso rejoined McLaren in 2015, hoping the Honda partnership would secure his third title. The team remains optimistic about future success, despite current challenges.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar and discovered alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defense admitted to lax adherence to licensing laws. The judge criticized Ms. O'Neill's poor record and fined her £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry surpassed his previous record of 272 three-pointers by hitting eight in the game. He also contributed nine assists, while Klay Thompson added 26 points to help the Warriors avoid a three-game losing streak. For the Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In another game, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points for the Bulls, who went on a 39-8 run to start the second half. Derrick Rose scored 12 points in his continued comeback from injury. Hassan Whiteside led the Heat with 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade struggled, scoring nine points on 4-for-20 shooting.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, initially believed to be a competition winner, showcased his impressive free-kick skills at Melwood. Van Velzen, known for his free-kick videos, wowed the players, revealing his true talent. The experience was thrilling for van Velzen, who enjoyed pretending to be an average fan and seeing the players' reactions. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the forward's famous slogan from a past match.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy (ovary removal). A study found that this procedure cuts the risk of dying from breast cancer by more than 60% for BRCA1 mutation carriers, but not for BRCA2 carriers. The 20-year survival rate for breast cancer patients with these mutations was 77.4%, with a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The protective effect is immediate and lasts for 15 years, especially if performed within two years of diagnosis. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered in treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Genetic tests are available for those likely to have BRCA mutations, which are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Other studies also support the survival benefits of ovary removal for women with a history of breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am as they lingered on the tracks. The train, heading from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for nearly three hours but none of the 166 passengers were injured, although one man received treatment for an illness during the delay. The couple, who may have lived in a homeless camp, were pronounced dead at the scene. The train continued its journey after the delay.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. Despite his significant contributions, including aiding in the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro is now facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship after he went public with his situation, leaving him living illegally in the U.S. and unable to collect social security benefits. Toro fears for his life if deported to Colombia and feels betrayed by the U.S. government for not honoring their promise.

The U.S. body regulating internet addresses is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal practices involving the '.sucks' domain. This domain has been used to charge high fees to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies to protect their reputations. ICANN, which initially approved the domain, is reconsidering after complaints from industry groups. Vox Populi charges around $2,499 annually for these domains, which some call a "shakedown scheme." ICANN has contacted U.S. and Canadian regulators and may take action if the company's practices are deemed illegal.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The case was reopened, and DNA from the exhumed body led police to the mother, who had concealed her pregnancy and placed the baby in the pond. She was initially suspected of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn. The baby, named Peter, was reburied with a new headstone. Police ruled out foul play, and the mother may face charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. Advances in DNA technology were crucial in solving the case.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of Young's moving taxi. The incident occurred five years ago when Young, mistakenly believing Hicks intended to evade the fare, drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. Hicks, feeling unlawfully detained, jumped from the vehicle at over 20mph, resulting in devastating injuries that left him needing lifelong care. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the exact amount is yet to be determined. The judge decided on a 50% reduction in the damages payable, with Hicks also receiving £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties have permission to appeal.

Several tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, with one spotted near Goddard and others in southwestern Kansas. The storms posed risks to various communities, and nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as particularly dangerous. Missouri also experienced severe weather, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago. Rockhold plans to adopt an aggressive strategy, likening himself to a bull against Machida's matador style, aiming to dominate by cutting off Machida's movement and exploiting his weaknesses. Despite respecting Machida's long-standing career and martial arts skills, Rockhold is confident in his diverse fighting abilities and preparation. Machida, coming off a win against CB Dollaway, is also confident, believing his technique and strategy can secure him a victory and a title shot. Both fighters acknowledge the high stakes, with the winner potentially earning a title shot.

A light general aviation aircraft in Fort Pierce, Florida, landed without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. The incident was captured on video, showing the plane's propellers hitting the ground and the wings bouncing. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The video maker noted the unforgettable sound of the propellers hitting the runway and expressed amazement that the engines were not destroyed. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is commonly caused by human error or mechanical fault.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance but pledged to support him until the season's end. Despite Toure's determination to stay, City is open to offers for him as they plan to revamp their squad. Pellegrini dismissed the idea of resting Toure, who has faced criticism during City's poor campaign. City, struggling in the league, will play West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the team's underperformance and support for Pellegrini. Additionally, West Ham's Sam Allardyce advised Aaron Cresswell against moving to City, citing past examples of limited playtime for English players.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will remain in the UK after his Italian sentence was dropped. Convicted in absentia in 1999 for mafia association and given a seven-year sentence, Rancadore lost his extradition battle in February. However, his case expired in October, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Italian law nullifies sentences after a period exceeding double the penalty time. The Italian Supreme Court must still hear the case. Rancadore's solicitor expressed confidence that he will be discharged from proceedings, allowing him to live peacefully in England. The case's handling faced criticism for wasting time and resources, with legal experts highlighting procedural delays and errors by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. Trained by Paul Nicholls, Mr. Mole is competing against Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This race will be McCoy's last Grade One race, with his final day of professional riding set for Saturday. McCoy announced his retirement after winning on Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other competitors include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia, who was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body after 40 years. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance, and Ritter's then-husband had advised her against seeing the body and photos to preserve her last memory of Marcia alive. Despite declining to see the photos for decades, Ritter requested to view them last year and was horrified by the images. Barrett, who had a history of sex crimes, was convicted of Marcia's murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case had been Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until DNA evidence linked Barrett to the crime.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters to complete his career grand slam, a feat achieved by only five other players. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta National as the most pivotal day of his career, teaching him valuable lessons. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is confident he will eventually win the green jacket, viewing it as a career-long goal. He aims to use the golf course as a sanctuary from external pressures, similar to how he managed distractions during his successful 2014 season.

The passage summarizes trending stories from the past week. Highlights include a rare quadruple rainbow in New York, exotic dancers at wakes in rural China facing a crackdown, Robert Downey Jr.'s tense interview, the #kyliejennerchallenge for lip plumping, 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past, a controversial prom-posal, Ewan McGregor cast in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer, a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombing his son.

Hundreds of children were hospitalized last year in England due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), with 272 cases reported, though the actual number may be higher. Research indicates that at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 affected babies annually. Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome highlights the severity and under-diagnosis of the issue. A case example is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who has severe disabilities due to FAS. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol intake, but some experts, like Mitchell, advocate for complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as "boomerang boy," attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. Wielding an axe, he demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty but was tackled by owner Sab Dhillon. Dhillon's wife, Sam, assisted by hitting McKerry with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. McKerry was arrested by police minutes later and has been jailed for six years after pleading guilty to attempted robbery. McKerry, notorious for his repeated offenses since age 12, earned his nickname for always returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks and must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, near Halifax, and were given bail conditions requiring them to live at the Stadacona naval base, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after a hockey game, involving a young woman in her early 20s. The sailors are forbidden from contacting the victim and witnesses, cannot leave Nova Scotia, and must return to court on May 27. The charges carry a potential 14-year prison sentence, and the investigation is ongoing.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, faced a distressing incident when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse due to her son RJ's rare skin condition, Netherton's syndrome. This condition, affecting only 70 people worldwide, causes RJ's skin to appear red, scaly, and inflamed. Valerie regularly applies creams to manage his symptoms. Despite this, she and RJ endure public ignorance and bullying, often being mistaken for signs of abuse. Valerie discovered the correct diagnosis through a Facebook group and now follows a strict skincare regimen for RJ. She hopes for greater awareness and understanding of the condition as RJ grows older.

Campaigners against Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts are celebrating as Transport for London (TfL) has decided to remove the controversial posters from the London Underground. The adverts, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, with a Change.org petition garnering over 50,000 signatures and the Advertising Standards Authority receiving more than 200 complaints. TfL stated the removal was due to the end of the paid advertising period, but noted the public reaction. The campaign has faced significant criticism on social media, with many accusing it of promoting unhealthy body images. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming it aimed to promote fitness and health, despite receiving threats and a bomb scare. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints, while sales of protein powder continue to rise in the UK.

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% shortly after the general election, despite political leaders' promises to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its decision to nearly double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which affects his Witney constituency. From May 17, off-peak return fares from Charlbury to London will increase from £33.30 to £62.40. FGW claims the changes align the North Cotswolds route with other services and offers cheaper advanced single tickets. Other rail companies, like London Midlands and Virgin, are also raising fares, with increases ranging from 22% to 24.5%. Virgin defends its hikes, stating they primarily affect "Virgin trains-only fares," which are cheaper than competitors' tickets.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals in Oldham. The attack occurred while he and his new wife, Elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts. The couple had been married for just three weeks. Young confronted the attackers after they began throwing stones at his property, resulting in a serious injury to his left eye. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The incident has left the couple feeling unsafe, prompting them to move to a different location. Police are investigating the attack, which appears to have no clear motive and may have been a case of yobs "messing around." They urge anyone with information to contact them.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident that also resulted in his father's death. After an ankle operation, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Poynton will be available for the start of the season and is committed to the county until the end of 2016. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence and performance.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually. The cancer had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his treatment, Harley decorated his radiotherapy mask like a Ninja Turtle to feel braver, which caught the attention of hospital staff and media. After a year of intensive treatment, including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley was declared cancer-free. His story gained widespread attention, leading to support from Nickelodeon and recognition from Cancer Research UK. Harley's family is overjoyed and hopeful for his future, with regular check-ups planned to ensure he remains cancer-free.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood is impressed with the 19-year-old's performance, particularly in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Grealish is currently at the center of a selection dilemma between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish should prioritize securing his place in the Villa first team. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees that club performance should come first, with the international decision to follow. Grealish has played for Ireland's youth teams, but England is also interested in him.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at various airports for private jets, a concern for wealthy travelers. It highlights that these fees can vary significantly, with some unexpected airports charging the highest amounts. The trend of private jet travel is growing, with millions of flights recorded in the US and Europe, and the market valued at trillions of dollars. The busiest times for private jet travel are during major sporting events. The passage lists the top 10 most expensive airports for landing fees, with three Japanese airports—Haneda, Narita, and Kansai—topping the list. Other notable mentions include airports in Toronto, Darwin, Bristol, Dublin, LaGuardia, and Salzburg.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy licked her treat slowly, Cooper devoured his in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, mentioned that Cooper always eats quickly, so she ensures Daisy gets her share first. A video of this outing has garnered over seven million views. Despite some criticism for feeding her dogs ice cream, Gallegos defends the treat, citing Cooper's good health and her past experience with another dog. The dogs also enjoy other fast food treats, as shown in another video where they visit Starbucks for a "pup-uccino."

Gary Locke, who previously served as interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager with a three-year contract. Locke, a former Hearts manager, initially joined Kilmarnock as an assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and took over as interim manager in February after Johnston resigned. Since taking charge, Locke has led the team to six wins out of seven games. He will discuss his new role at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. The oils, manufactured by doTERRA, are applied to his head and neck to keep him calm and focused but have been deemed a distraction by teachers. Despite a complaint from a teacher's aide and a letter from the school board citing the oils as a problem, Kemp insists on their positive impact and plans to fight the decision. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, framing the issue as a health concern. The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A fire obliterated a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, the Hamptons, on Wednesday at 3 PM, destroying 90 condos. The blaze, which melted paint off nearby buildings, produced smoke visible from three miles away. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, they could not enter the building. The cause of the fire is unknown but is under investigation, with some claims suggesting it started near a parked car. Residents, including Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, who lost everything, were devastated. The Sandpiper complex, used as a holiday home from May to November, was completely destroyed.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, approaching her 89th birthday, enjoying a ride in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. Despite her age and a knee injury, the Queen remains an avid equestrian, preferring to ride without a helmet to preserve her hairstyle. Her lifelong love of horses began at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy. The Queen breeds various horse breeds, including Fell ponies, at her Hampton Court and Balmoral studs. The passage also details the history and characteristics of Fell ponies, a breed dating back to the Neolithic period, known for their docility and hardiness.

An argument over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors resulted in tragedy when 55-year-old Leon Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The incident occurred after Yeaman, known for making noise while drunk, was confronted by Pama, who was trying to sleep before his early shift. Pama, who has no history of violence, claimed he hit Yeaman blindly during the altercation. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the job. Police set up a sting operation with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, capturing Simonova on camera detailing her gruesome plans. She was arrested after handing over expense money and now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who had left Simonova for a classmate, expressed relief at her arrest.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea football manager, revealed he talks to God daily but never about football, and he keeps his professional and family life separate. He and his family are aware of poverty and have worked with the World Food Programme. Mourinho has a strong faith, prays daily, and attends church in Portugal when he feels the need. Despite his competitive and emotional professional demeanor, he considers himself a good person, supportive of others, and acknowledges making mistakes. Chelsea is currently leading the league, and Mourinho was fined earlier for comments about a campaign against his team.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" on April 1, taking over from current host Drew Carey. Barker, who originally hosted the show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, appeared energetic at 91 and led the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing the hosting duties back to Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker performed seamlessly.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested early Friday morning in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house and was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The arrest occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE, and Baldwin's security clearance was revoked, and he was placed on leave. Baldwin, who is part of the Foreign Missions Branch, was to be arraigned later that day. This incident follows another recent case of alleged misconduct by a high-ranking supervisor, adding to a series of controversies involving the agency. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating both incidents.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up images of a hungry lion at a safari park. Saeed left the safety of his car and crept to within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with his camera. The clicking sound of the camera alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to retreat rapidly. He managed to scramble back into his car just as the lion jumped towards him. Reflecting on the incident, Saeed acknowledged the danger and expressed doubt about repeating such a risky endeavor.

New York City police have released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, who was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn. Despite paramedics' efforts, she was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, believed to be the name "Monique" within a heart topped with a rose. Police are seeking public assistance in identifying her and are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and finding they couldn't afford traditional property. Over a year and a half, they constructed the home using wood and steel, creating a cozy, nearly self-sufficient living space in Nelson, New Zealand. The home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is surrounded by nature. The project cost them about $25,000, and they plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers have found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not use iPads or use them individually. This study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 kindergarten students and revealed that shared iPad users scored about 30 points higher than their peers. The research suggests that the collaborative learning facilitated by sharing the devices is key to these improved outcomes. These findings challenge the skepticism of some educational leaders about the use of technology in non-IT classes and indicate that schools might need to reconsider how tablets are utilized, especially in early grades. Blackwell is set to present her findings at an upcoming conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, owned by Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China, has captured hearts with a video showing its unsteady but determined steps. Despite frequent near-tumbles, the piglet, nicknamed "super pig," manages to balance and mix with its fully-legged siblings. Villagers have flocked to see the piglet, reminiscent of a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also gained fame for its unique way of walking.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana when he was hit by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was released. The race saw many cars struggling with traction due to prior rain. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro. CCTV footage shows Severiano smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her face 10 times, and then shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, citing jealousy over men looking at her. The couple had been married for only four days. After the murder, Severiano attempted to flee but was apprehended by police, who found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life imprisonment.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," shared her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing she nearly took her own life. In a candid interview, Wilson, 41, discussed how anxiety led her to feel that life was not worth living. She attributed her feelings to a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and isolation from family. Despite her struggles, Wilson has recently found some peace and believes that depression and anxiety are closely linked. She emphasizes the need to acknowledge this connection to better address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson now accepts her anxiety and notes that it is becoming increasingly common, with one in three Australian women experiencing it in their lifetime. For support, she encourages contacting organizations like Beyond Blue and Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and attacked her when she refused to leave. Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who won't leave. Prosecutors dropped the charges, deeming Curtin's actions justified. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin and trying to rekindle her relationship with Curtin's boyfriend, who had struggled with heroin addiction. Curtin has since moved on, living with her parents, and the boyfriend is not involved in their child's life.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats, but when her owner included a broccoli spear, she showed disgust and spat it out. Despite this, other videos show Gemma enjoying time with her human family, including sleeping and hanging out. The hope is that the two children she lives with will not mimic her aversion to vegetables.

HSBC has issued an apology after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which was meant for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, led to explicit content after the awards were discontinued in 2011 and the domain registration lapsed. HSBC removed the hyperlink upon discovering the error and clarified that it has no association with the external site. The bank assured the public that its website remains secure and apologized for any inconvenience caused.

A 13-year-old boy from Maryland, named Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom with his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, Marcus provided calm and clear instructions to the dispatcher, ensuring their rescue. He soothed his sister and guided firefighters to their location. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, rescuing both children. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped and were also hospitalized.

Amazing pictures have emerged of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as a "beautiful supernatural" display caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar event occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is caused by the single-celled phytoplankton Noctiluca scintillans, which blooms in spring and autumn and emits light as a defense mechanism.

New genetic marker tests for breast cancer can determine the aggressiveness of tumors, potentially sparing patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened to assess the risk of recurrence. For some women, the test can show a risk as low as five percent, comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. Traditionally, most breast cancer patients undergo chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, despite severe side effects. Experts believe some women have a lower risk of recurrence and may not need chemotherapy. The EndoPredict test, costing around £2,500 and mostly available privately, can help patients make informed decisions. Surgeons advocate for its NHS availability, citing cost savings. Case in point, Becca Cornford, a mother of three, avoided chemotherapy after her EndoPredict test showed a low recurrence risk.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict 'no touching' rule at sea, indicating pregnancies likely occurred before boarding or during leave. This data follows the case of Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK amid claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, they made up about 9% of personnel. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013, with similar evacuations from Iraq. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and they are flown back on flights typically for injured troops. Most pregnancies were likely conceived before deployment, though some may have occurred on tour.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's prime minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The discovery coincided with a court's approval to restart two nuclear reactors, a move that is controversial in Japan due to safety concerns following the Fukushima disaster. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle containing cesium, was not immediately harmful but prompted fears of future terrorist attacks, especially with upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit.
