The report also raises concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, accusing it of deforestation, which Olam refutes, claiming responsible and transparent practices.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law permitted dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they were outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only played from the bench recently. David Nugent might return after a groin injury, and Jacob Butterfield is aiming for a recall after scoring as a substitute in the last game.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. While YouTube denies that authorities can filter content, the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) can request the blocking of offensive material, which Google may restrict after review. The ban, imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," led to protests and deaths in Pakistan. Activists call for transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the government. Google has also launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing pressure to withdraw from the upcoming presidential election process due to a potential conflict of interest, as he shares Swiss-Italian nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association, has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down. Bility cites Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which mandates the replacement of committee members with conflicts of interest. Scala previously withdrew from the 2015 elections for similar reasons, but his spokesman argues that no conflict exists this time as there is no incumbent president among the five candidates. Bility, who was denied participation in the election, has pledged his support to Prince Ali and is urging other African nations to do the same. The election to replace Sepp Blatter will occur in 18 days in Zurich, with candidates including Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an incident at Harford Attachments in Spar Road around 09:00 BST on Monday. They were working in a paint-spraying area, and their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search revealed a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported significant progress in forensic inquiries and witness statements. The Health and Safety Executive is also involved, with inspectors and electrical safety experts gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf but avoided it by apologizing. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup but re-entered after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, leading to a reduced fine. Equatorial Guinea hosted the 2015 finals on short notice. Tunisia's dispute with Caf stemmed from a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a demand for an apology. Tunisia clarified they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption but criticized the referee's appointment. A meeting with Caf's president resolved the issue, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia will compete in Group A, and Morocco in Group F, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive finals appearance.

The passage describes a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a game at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. Manchester City had two players, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho, sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Aguero received a four-match ban for a high and late challenge on David Luiz, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for clashing with Fabregas. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Mae gan Gymru a rhannau eraill o'r DU gyfraddau goresgyn canser isel. Mae cynllun peilot yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn targedu cleifion sydd â symptomau aneglur o ganser. Mae'r cynllun yn deillio o astudiaeth o systemau diagnostig yn Nenmarc, sy'n dangos gwelliannau mewn cyfraddau goresgyn canser. Mae'r cynllun yn caniatáu i feddygon teulu gyfeirio cleifion at ganolfannau diagnostig o fewn saith diwrnod, gan obeithio cyflymu diagnosis a thriniaeth. Bydd 40 o feddygon yn cymryd rhan, gyda'r nod o weld chwe chlaf yr wythnos. Os yw'r cynllun yn llwyddiannus, bydd yn cael ei ehangu i fyrddau iechyd eraill.

England won the match at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series against Pakistan. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's improvement after self-reflection. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series. Former players Geoffrey Boycott and Michael Vaughan commented on England's strong performance and Pakistan's broken spirit. Misbah acknowledged Pakistan's poor shot selection and expressed hope for improvement. The third Test will begin on 3 August after Pakistan's tour game against Worcestershire.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his team. Forwards coach McBryde will be the head coach for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his excitement and honor at the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde, with discussions ongoing to finalize the management team. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips and Union chairman Gareth Davies, who is also on the Lions' selection panel, believe that the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour will benefit Welsh rugby by providing valuable development opportunities and inspiration.

Hull City overcame an early setback to secure a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending a six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty put Southampton ahead, but Hull, despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to injuries, turned the game around in the second half. Substitute Robert Snodgrass equalized in the 61st minute and then assisted Michael Dawson's header two minutes later. Southampton pressed for an equalizer, but Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas cleared a last-minute effort off the line. Hull remains in the bottom three but gains confidence heading into the international break.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist was a local resident, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This decision was criticized by both the opposition and EU officials. Macedonia has faced turmoil since the recordings were released in 2015, which allegedly show ministers involved in vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called the move illegal and urged protests, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn stated it jeopardizes Macedonia's EU membership prospects. Zaev has been releasing recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of extensive corruption and wiretapping, which the government denies, instead accusing Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis emphasizes the need for a manager who can prevent relegation, noting the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if they go down. Swansea, promoted in 2011, had a reputation for exciting football but have struggled since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements have diluted the "Swansea Way." Despite this, he feels the current squad can avoid relegation and stresses the importance of staying up for the club and the community.

The Daggers, who joined League One in 2010, needed a win to maintain their survival hopes but were relegated after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet's winner sealed their fate. Dagenham, who first entered the Football League in 2007, will return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led them to League One. The team has struggled defensively and offensively this season, with a poor goal difference and fewer goals from key striker Jamie Cureton. Still, in his third spell as manager, is committed to helping the team gain promotion next season. Leyton Orient, now two points from the play-off spots, recently removed player-manager Kevin Nolan, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing professionalism and the importance of winning games for the fans.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to the club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised Gerrard's appointment, noting Gerrard's aspirations to become a manager and his readiness to learn the necessary skills. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left in 2015 to join LA Galaxy, retired in November after a 19-year career. Although linked to the manager's job at MK Dons, Gerrard felt it was too soon. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

McManus scored early to give Morton the lead, followed by a deflected goal from Ross Forbes. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa before half-time, but further goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in poor conditions in three now-closed Birmingham locations, with operators of illegal schools facing up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are considering more regulations for places teaching over 6 to 8 hours weekly. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw reported inspectors were shocked by the conditions, with 18 unregulated schools, mostly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, investigated recently. He expressed concerns about child abuse and radicalization risks, noting these cases might be just the "tip of the iceberg." Schools teaching over 20 hours weekly must register, but some part-time education centers exploit home education laws to operate illegally. Sir Michael criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice. The government has funded six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, targeting all religious groups. The education secretary plans to prosecute identified unregistered schools, with government consultation on further regulation ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is part of a broader movement to establish the Scottish Borders as a region of distilling excellence. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the small scale of their operation, which fits into a cowshed, and their focus on capturing local flavors from the Teviot valley. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praises the distillery's alignment with local sourcing principles. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, reflecting the local landscape and the female-led production team.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after being hit by a vehicle driven by Gary Green at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact on their family and emphasized the dangers of driving under the influence. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others, prosecuted under health and safety laws since the incident occurred on private land. An investigation revealed Green's reckless behavior led to the accident.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches with his new club, Barcelona, following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Although he remains banned from competitive matches, he can now participate in all football-related activities. Suarez's public presentation at Barcelona will be held at Camp Nou, and his competitive debut is expected against Real Madrid on October 26. The Cas ruling upheld most of Fifa's sanctions for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup but deemed the complete ban from football activities excessive. Suarez's legal team argued that Fifa's punishment was disproportionate. Despite the partial success of the appeal, the world players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not significantly reduced. Suarez has a history of similar offenses and has previously faced suspensions for biting and racial abuse.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa from Lithuania. The race involved a 380-metre course with various obstacles. Rich attributed their success to a week of training. The event featured diverse pairings, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. Rich and Anna will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond announced that job roles at the DVLA would change with the scrapping of paper car tax discs in October, transitioning to an electronic system. This change raised concerns about job losses among the 5,000 DVLA workers. In response to a query from Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, Hammond assured that job reductions would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed this assurance, acknowledging the benefits of the new system and expressing relief that employees would be redeployed.

The passage discusses Hungary's defiance against the European Union's objections to its domestic policies, including tight controls on asylum seekers, a higher education law, and proposed legislation on non-governmental organisations (NGOs). Hungary's Foreign Minister stated that the EU should not interfere in these matters and confirmed Poland's support in vetoing any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights. The EU's concerns include the potential closure of the Central European University and the stigmatization of NGOs. Despite protests and warnings from the EU, Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, remains firm on its stance.

The passage discusses the casting and production details of the live-action "Beauty and the Beast" film. Mrs. Potts will be played by an unnamed star, originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The film is set to release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, with filming starting at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist diagnosed with multiple cancers, passed away recently. Despite his illness, he felt fortunate in life. Gill, who joined the Sunday Times in 1993, was celebrated for his exceptional writing and wit. His final column will be published in the Sunday Times. Colleagues and notable figures praised his unique style and contributions to journalism. Known for his controversial articles, Gill's career spanned art reviews, Tatler, and the Sunday Times. He overcame dyslexia, attended prestigious schools, and had two marriages, with four children. His illness led to his engagement to long-term partner Nicola Formby.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, where he wore a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, a symbol with historical significance in Mongolia. He was reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked, resulting in a coma. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but claims local reports are distorted. The swastika, though associated with Nazis, is a traditional symbol in Mongolia. The Russian diplomat accused of the attack has not been identified or arrested, and the case is under investigation. The musician's lawyer and family deny he made any Nazi-related gestures or statements during the performance.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. They are due in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, prompting a security review by the Metropolitan Police.

Glamorgan's innings was highlighted by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, despite being dropped early. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets in cloudy conditions. Aneurin Donald added a quick 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten helped secure a bonus point. Gloucestershire also struggled with the bat, ending the day evenly balanced. Glamorgan was led by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck injury. Selman expressed relief at returning to form after a series of low scores, while Taylor was satisfied with Gloucestershire's bowling performance and anticipated a challenging batting session.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making threats online to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a false report to ambush and shoot police officers. The threats were made while he was drunk, and he has a prior conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Hughes will be sentenced next week. His legal team claimed he did not intend to carry out the threats. North Wales Police were particularly concerned as Hughes was on bail for firearms offences at the time. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7, thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase was disrupted by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, including key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire, aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, started well but faltered after Matthew Waite dropped Davies, who went on to score significantly. Meaker's crucial wickets turned the game, and despite efforts from Bresnan and Waite, Yorkshire fell short. Surrey's captain praised the team's collective effort, while Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment over missed opportunities.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST due to a failing pump unable to manage incoming water. Holyhead coastguards responded, and the RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Scotland team at next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, which include exams in May. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, expressed disappointment but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She remains optimistic about her future in athletics, targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and potentially participating in future Olympics. Muir recently set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds.

Robbie Savage's BBC Sport column discusses Liverpool's struggles to replicate their previous season's title challenge. He attributes this to unrealistic expectations, poor transfer decisions, and the loss of key players like Luis Suarez and the injured Daniel Sturridge. Savage criticizes Liverpool's current strikers and their lack of intensity and pressing, which has led to fewer goals and a need to chase games. He also highlights defensive issues despite significant spending, noting the absence of a commanding leader at the back. Savage suggests a lineup for the upcoming Chelsea match, emphasizing the need for a solid midfield and active full-backs. He also reflects on Steven Gerrard's challenges, both physical and mental, in extending his career and maintaining his performance levels. Despite recent setbacks, Savage believes Gerrard remains a crucial player for Liverpool.

A £45m facility in Kilmarnock will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed his delight in preserving McIlvanney's name, noting his passion for education. McIlvanney, initially an English teacher, became a full-time writer in 1975, gaining fame with his first novel, "Remedy Is None," and earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He wrote the Laidlaw trilogy and other notable works, and was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster. McIlvanney passed away on 5 December at his home in Glasgow.

A section of the town near the swimming pool was evacuated due to the discovery of a sea mine, believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents nearby were advised to stay indoors and open windows, while an exclusion zone was enforced on the river. The evacuation impacted three streets, with safety advice extended to those within 500 meters of the mine. A half-mile exclusion zone at sea was also established, disrupting ferry services. Authorities emphasized the evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger. The mine's condition made it unclear how much explosive material remained, necessitating its relocation for safety. Inverclyde Council thanked the community for their cooperation.

The passage discusses the allocation of funding for Olympic and Paralympic sports by UK Sport for the Tokyo 2020 Games. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have lost funding, while cycling's budget was reduced by over £4m. Badminton, despite winning a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding completely removed, a decision criticized by Badminton England's chief executive. Overall, £345m will be invested in 31 sports, £2m less than for the Rio Games. UK Sport aims for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Despite the cuts, the government remains committed to funding. Judo's funding increased slightly, while basketball, handball, and volleyball, which lost funding in previous years, criticized UK Sport for neglecting team sports. Funding for new sports added for Tokyo 2020, including baseball/softball, karate, and others, is still pending based on medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth, will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and some residents, councillors voted in favor of the development, citing benefits to tourism and improved living conditions for older people. The new site will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. The decision faced opposition due to concerns about the loss of historic character and the scale of the new development.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was off-duty in Brecon when he was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely, 24, who will be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Boyd, from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was in Brecon for training and was attacked outside a bar called The Cellar. CCTV showed Vallely, who had been drinking heavily, beating Boyd until he was unconscious and then dragging his body away. The attack was condemned by police and Boyd's family, who described him as loving and full of life, and expressed their grief and loss.

Andrew Travers left his position at Barnet Council by "mutual agreement" following an error where voters were turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. Travers expressed positive sentiments about his tenure, and the council acknowledged his contributions. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. On election day, many voters were not on the register and were told to return later. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, but concerns about the fairness of the election were raised. Travers attributed the issue to electoral registration lists. The council's review will conclude by the end of May, with findings presented to the General Functions Committee, and discussions are ongoing to determine the investigation's leader.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where Josh Gillies initially put Gateshead ahead with a free-kick. Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised his team's second-half performance and the quality of the winning goal. Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment over his team's second-half performance and missed opportunities. The match concluded with Gateshead maintaining their lead despite Wrexham's efforts.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan ranks lowest, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to create a global broadband network using a constellation of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000. The initiative focuses on providing internet access worldwide, particularly to schools, and requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing towards high volume and low cost, similar to car and plane production. Airbus, partnering with OneWeb, has set up new assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and plans additional lines in Florida. The project involves an extensive rocket launch campaign, with over 20 Soyuz rockets scheduled to deploy clusters of satellites. OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking further financing. The UK Space Agency will oversee licensing, with a focus on debris mitigation to prevent space collisions. OneWeb commits to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and equipping them with devices for potential retrieval. The new manufacturing methods may disrupt the satellite industry, though bespoke satellites will still be necessary for specific missions.

The passage discusses the financial pressures on Scotland due to the UK government's recent spending review, which Scottish Deputy First Minister John Swinney claims will result in a 12.5% reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20. Swinney criticizes the UK government's austerity measures, stating that essential services like schools, hospitals, and police will be protected despite the cuts. The UK government counters that Scotland will have an additional £390m to spend next year, and Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget plan, criticizing both the UK government's and the Scottish government's approaches to austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their carers due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities. Ordinary accessible toilets often do not meet the needs of those requiring additional assistance, such as a hoist or multiple carers. Campaigners are advocating for Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced facilities, to be made compulsory in larger buildings. Personal stories highlight the emotional and practical difficulties caused by inadequate facilities. Despite logistical and financial barriers, some organizations, like Arsenal Football Club, have successfully implemented these toilets, demonstrating the positive impact on accessibility and inclusion.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of imposing excessive rents and high fees on franchisees. McDonald's defends its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its licensees and supports them in operating their businesses. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, who argue that McDonald's abuses its market position, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and may launch an investigation. The consumer organizations allege that McDonald's forces franchisees into long contracts and charges above-market rents, leading to reduced consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, contributing significantly to the company's global revenue.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood, part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Initially intended to be an appendix operation, doctors found and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The hashtag, started by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father works, went viral, garnering global support. A mystery donor funded a billboard, and the campaign has seen significant engagement on social media, with updates shared widely. Josh's family and friends, along with global supporters, continue to rally for his recovery.

The passage discusses the planned closure of Brecon Barracks as part of a reorganization of UK military buildings and regiments. Conservative MP Chris Davies criticized the decision, highlighting the barracks' historical significance and its role in the local economy, particularly concerning high unemployment and military tourism. He plans to launch a petition against the closure. The reorganization includes creating a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and closing other facilities in Wales by 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but expressed concern over the impact on people's livelihoods.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that Britain may need to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal, despite fishing communities heavily supporting Brexit. The House of Lords report warns that these communities risk being marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the UK fishing industry, which sees Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters. However, the report notes that UK fishing is a small part of the economy and that continued market access to the EU is crucial. Trade-offs may be necessary, including granting EU boats access to UK waters. The report also suggests retaining some CFP elements and warns of potential complications if the UK adopts different fisheries management regimes across its nations. Despite concerns, some in the industry are optimistic about post-Brexit opportunities. The government aims to balance trade freedom with sustainable fisheries management.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about the US National Security Agency's (NSA) extensive surveillance activities. The NSA, through programs like Prism, accessed vast amounts of data from major tech companies, including chat logs, voice traffic, and social media posts. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon. While officials argue these measures are necessary for national security, critics raise privacy concerns. Different countries have varying data protection laws, but US laws like the Patriot Act allow extensive access to data, even from non-Americans. The involvement of other governments in Prism remains unclear, and privacy advocates warn of widespread privacy violations.

The passage discusses the backers of OpenAI, including notable figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, and companies such as Infosys and Amazon Web Services. OpenAI aims to conduct research focused on positive human impact without financial constraints. There are concerns about AI potentially threatening humanity, as expressed by Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, though some experts believe the risk is minimal. OpenAI's mission is to advance AI in a way that benefits humanity and is safely distributed. The venture plans to spend only a small portion of its $1 billion funding in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, gaining thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit. Despite his brain injury affecting his speech, he now speaks unaided and retains his personality and humor. He dedicates 12 hours daily to gym and rehab, uses crutches, and raises funds for military charities, including Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, noted the overwhelming support and increased mail and email traffic. Facebook suggested he create a public page due to his popularity. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 carriers over 8,000 miles, concluding at the London Games on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, remaining unchanged after three years of increases. Real median household income fell by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013 and has extended his contract with the club until 2019. Known for his prowess in short-format cricket, Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent, contribution to the team's T20 Blast victory, and positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler, currently playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, will rejoin Lancashire for an upcoming T20 Blast game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders having until 23 January to express interest. No preservation proposals have been submitted, and interested parties are finalizing bids with viewings in late February and March. A final decision is expected in the spring. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but also hopes to save at least one ship, suggesting it could become a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for the best financial return. The Type 22 frigates, originally anti-submarine ships, evolved into powerful combatants with advanced weapons and command systems, serving as flagships with about 280 crew. Last year, HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political tensions, leading to instability and international isolation. A coup by indigenous Fijians in 1987 overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, resulting in a series of adverse events, including a constitution promoting indigenous supremacy, which was later withdrawn. Another coup in 2000, led by George Speight, involved the hostage-taking of the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and others, damaging the economy and Fiji's international standing. Continued tensions led to a bloodless military coup in 2006. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 but was reinstated after holding free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation. Fiji's economy, though diverse with industries like sugar, tourism, mining, and services, struggles with trade and budget deficits, making it a significant aid recipient.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is striving to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline due to attacks on shipments. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where significant civilian casualties have been reported. Mekdad denied targeting civilians and accused the US of supporting terrorists. Conflicting reports emerged about the control of Aleppo's central prison, with state media denying rebel claims of seizing it. Syria has declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but only 4% has been removed so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns about delays, while the OPCW acknowledged security issues affecting the process. Mekdad affirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The passage discusses the Booker Prize shortlist for the year, highlighting Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others" as the favorite to win. This year marks the first time the prize is open to all English-language authors, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith), two Americans (Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler), and one Australian (Richard Flanagan). Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a special edition of their book. The passage provides brief summaries of the nominated works and mentions that Fowler's book is the best-selling among them. It also notes that the judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes several other notable figures. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton for "The Luminaries." The announcement will be covered by the BBC.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing a court ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide whether to grant an appeal and if so, whether it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is fighting to maintain his privacy against the Sun on Sunday, which wants to publish details of his alleged extra-marital activities. The Court of Appeal judges ruled that the confidentiality of the allegations had likely been lost due to widespread dissemination on the internet and other media, making a permanent injunction unlikely.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased in August for £345.5 million. The new owners are planning improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have met with the council to resolve potential planning issues and view Fosse Park as an investment opportunity. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to improve parking, congestion, and the quality of common areas to enhance the overall experience at Fosse Park.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy due to a "gay moment" and was delayed in Malaysia for content review by Disney. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit to the gay scene, as homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification," but the release date remains unannounced. Local cinemas have been refunding tickets. The "gay moment" involves LeFou's feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film sparked criticism online, with many netizens mocking the move.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people must obtain an HMO licence, which can cost around £1,000, though many avoid it despite potential fines up to £20,000, according to Southampton City Council. The council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally. Nadeem Khan from Shelter highlights tenant concerns about eviction and poor property conditions due to a shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, HMO licensing is required for properties with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, specific areas have designated licensing requirements introduced in 2013 and 2015. While most landlords comply, a minority resist, leading to prosecutions of one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to avoid a second election. Martin's party will facilitate a minority government but won't support a government programme. Water charges are a major issue, with a commission proposed to review Irish Water's future. Fianna Fáil wants to remove water charges immediately, while Fine Gael supports them. Post-election, Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour Party 7, but no majority government has been formed, and a taoiseach has not been elected.

The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire near Mallorca, leading to a rapid evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats. They were rescued by another ship, with three injured individuals taken to the hospital, one seriously. The fire's cause is unknown. Multiple ships, including two ferries, assisted in the rescue, and the passengers were transferred to the ferry Puglia, heading back to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were arranged to provide support upon their arrival. The Sorrento, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, may sink due to the fire. The distress signal was sent at 13:50 local time, and despite initial hopes to control the fire, a full evacuation was necessary.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs noted instances of people, including students, voting twice, which is illegal. They suggested better integration of council-run electoral registers to identify duplicates. Labour cautioned against making voter registration harder for young people. A record 46.8 million people registered for the 8 June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registrations after the snap poll announcement and before the deadline, with 2.9 million applications in six weeks. Duplicate applications remain a concern, with no direct link between local electoral registers and the online system, leading to significant administrative burdens. The watchdog recommended clearer registration information and a verification function. Despite efforts to inform people about registration, many submitted duplicate applications due to the ease of online registration. Voting twice in a general election is a serious offence, and the watchdog called for better cross-checking of electoral registers and pre-selection of constituencies for those registered in multiple places. Labour emphasized the need for police resources to address double voting but warned against measures that could hinder young voters.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, is believed to have committed suicide at age 40. Despite his early success, Phillips faced numerous legal troubles, including convictions for assault and a lengthy prison sentence. He was recently accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, and was awaiting trial. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips' intelligence and good qualities but also his struggle with anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating the Mercian Regiment's eight-year anniversary. Brigadier Andrew Williams awarded the promotion for the ram's "good behaviour." Derby XXX is the 30th mascot in a tradition dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in 1858. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season at Chatsworth Estate. His notable activities include helping to switch on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial event.

The passage describes a dramatic and emotional football match where Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund, advancing to the Europa League semi-finals. The match was marked by Liverpool's comeback from a 2-0 deficit, inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp's motivational leadership. Goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Dejan Lovren highlighted the team's resilience. Klopp's influence has transformed the team's mentality from doubt to belief, reminiscent of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League triumph. The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with fans and players united in their determination. Despite vulnerabilities in defense, Klopp's impact is evident, and the team is now closer to a Champions League spot.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK government representative Mr. Davis stated that the UK would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. He proposed monthly meetings for a two-way information flow, allowing devolved administrations to voice their views. Mr. Davis emphasized the importance of collaboration to secure the best deal for the UK. However, Mr. Russell from the Scottish government called for more transparency and clarity on the UK's strategic intentions, particularly regarding EU market access and single market membership, which he deemed crucial for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government is appealing a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50, with the Scottish government planning to oppose this appeal in the Supreme Court.

Dr. Sandra Corr conducts a thorough physical examination on Daisy, a cloned sheep, checking for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four clones from the same ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal. These sheep are closely monitored to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy. Concerns arose from Dolly's early death and osteoarthritis, prompting further cloning from the original cell line to investigate if cloning accelerates aging. The study, led by Prof. Kevin Sinclair, examines cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in these clones. Results, to be published soon, could impact the future of cloning, but currently, the cloned sheep appear healthy.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favorite won a race and will next compete in Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed, who previously beat Enable, secured a fifth Musidora win for Gosden and jockey Dettori, despite challenging soft ground conditions. Gosden is cautious about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes and will decide on participation after inspecting the course. Shutter Speed will prepare for France's Oaks, while Cracksman's participation in the Derby remains uncertain due to the short gap between races.

The passage describes the fluctuating performance of the pound against the dollar, euro, and yen amidst rising uncertainty over the UK's EU referendum. The volatility index has reached levels reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign downplays the pound's decline, noting it has only retreated to March levels. Investor anxiety is fueled by polls showing increased chances of a Leave vote and global economic concerns. Market reactions include significant drops in Asian stock markets and a decline in London's FTSE 100. Analysts predict heightened volatility in sterling as the referendum approaches. Hedge funds are betting on further declines in sterling, and the economic impact of a potential Brexit is causing market instability. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argues that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters, citing recent improvements in the UK's trade deficit.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. Despite a tough match against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games, and Braintree's own losing streak reaching three games, manager Cowley remained positive. He praised his team's efforts and acknowledged the challenges of being a part-time team, emphasizing their determination to embrace and enjoy the journey ahead.

The passage discusses the shift of planning decision responsibilities in Northern Ireland from the Planning Service to local councils starting April 2015. This change will allow elected politicians to make planning decisions, which some view as a positive move towards democratizing the planning system. Michael Corr of PLACE sees it as an opportunity for local councils to develop community plans. However, there are concerns about potential discrimination and lack of transparency, reminiscent of issues from the 1960s. Friends of the Earth stress the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency in political donations to prevent favoritism and ensure fair planning practices. Some local politicians oppose the move, fearing it could deter donors due to security concerns. The Northern Ireland Secretary has the authority to decide when to increase transparency regarding political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The incident occurred in Winchburgh, and the cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The charity described Teenie as "incredibly lucky" to survive. The shooting has raised concerns about airgun safety, with Scottish SPCA Ch Supt Mike Flynn advocating for the urgent implementation of airgun licensing. Despite a consultation by the Scottish government last year, where 87% of respondents opposed the licensing plan, the incident underscores the potential dangers of unregulated airgun use. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information to find the person responsible.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke, making him their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. This follows the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. Benteke, a 24-year-old Belgium international, was acquired by triggering a release clause in his contract with Aston Villa, where he scored 49 goals in 101 games. Benteke expressed his desire to win trophies and achieve great goals with Liverpool. The club struggled with scoring last season after selling Luis Suarez and dealing with Daniel Sturridge's injuries. Manager Brendan Rodgers aims to revive the attack with Benteke, alongside new signings Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the returning Divock Origi. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury but helped Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final last season. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both believe Benteke will succeed at Liverpool, highlighting his strength, speed, and goal-scoring ability.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence that tablet devices improve academic performance. It surveyed 671 state and independent schools, revealing that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, with 9% providing one per pupil. The highest usage was in academy schools. Despite the lack of definitive proof linking tablets to better results, head teachers noted positive impacts, such as increased motivation and family involvement. The number of tablets in schools is expected to double from 2014 to 2016. A separate study indicated that touch-screen devices help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The study also highlighted the pervasive role of technology in students' lives, with many taking devices to bed. Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School, supports tablet use, citing benefits like empowerment and alignment with modern life, though he acknowledges these benefits are hard to quantify in academic results.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs depicting children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images provide a social history of the city, showing changes in childhood experiences and special occasions. The oldest photo, from 1887, is of the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball. The exhibition also highlights the reality of child labor, with a portrait of a young maid from around 1900. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition aims to present both the joyful and challenging aspects of childhood. It runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival and may play against his former team on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is moving subject to international clearance, having previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs. It also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera signed the law in President Evo Morales's absence, emphasizing a balance between reality and legal standards. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia work to support their families, often in harsh conditions. The government aims to reduce extreme poverty with this law, despite the International Labour Organisation's (ILO) minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is reviewing the law for compliance with international child labor regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress and TV host, experienced a heart attack and described her ordeal on her blog. After feeling sudden nausea and aches, she looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day. The doctor found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell's symptoms began after helping a woman in her village home near New York. She did not call emergency services but later warned her readers to recognize heart attack symptoms and call 911. O'Donnell, known for roles in "Drop Dead Diva," "Will and Grace," and "Nip/Tuck," recently had her show on the Oprah Winfrey Network canceled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton after a fight with a group of youths trying to gain entry. The incident occurred in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT, and he was pronounced dead about an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but is in stable condition. Che had been invited to the party, which was well-supervised, and was not involved in the initial altercation. Police are seeking witnesses from the alleyway. A 21-year-old man and two boys, aged 15 and 16, have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old boy is held for possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a reorganization of the diagnostic process for cancer patients in Denmark, inspired by poor cancer survival rates over 15 years ago. A team from Wales visited Aarhus to learn about these changes. The new model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with clear cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for those with minor symptoms to quickly rule out serious conditions. These changes have improved survival rates and better organized patient diagnosis without overwhelming the system. The Danish approach emphasizes collaboration between GPs and specialists, offering potential lessons for Wales.

The UK government has decided to disband the OFT, and Powys has won the bid to take over its responsibilities. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or those breaching laws. Complaints about estate agents will still go to local authority trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders and refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team and hopes this role will demonstrate Powys's capability to handle more contracts and external work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of nurses and other health staff with additional training, following a Nuffield Trust review. The review found nurses and pharmacists already covering for doctors and GPs in some areas. While this could help address doctor shortages and adapt to the increasing focus on long-term care, unions caution against using it as a quick fix for NHS staffing issues. The Nuffield Trust emphasized the need for funding to support these changes. NHS Employers and union leaders agree on the potential benefits but stress the importance of maintaining quality training and support for doctors.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place after a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services until the road reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First's managing director, James Freeman, stated that while some services had resumed, it would take a few hours for all to return to normal, aiming for full service by the evening commute. He thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

Earlier this month, NRW estimated that the proposed lagoon would result in the annual deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout during their migration. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed these claims, arguing they lacked a clear scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggested a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is seen as a prototype for larger projects. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, with the Welsh Government expressing strong support but seeking clarity on the UK government's stance. NRW defended its estimates, stating they were based on extensive evidence and expert assessment.

The passage discusses the announcement by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster about the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and improve coordination of marketing activities within the agri-food sector, which employs nearly 100,000 people. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the initiative, highlighting its potential to boost export-led economic growth, though she notes it may affect other organizations, including her department.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to plant thousands of trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, organized by the Woodland Trust. This is part of a UK-wide project to plant millions of native trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. The four-year initiative aims to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood, honoring the 40,000 Irish lives lost in the conflict. The trust encourages local participation to contribute to this historical tribute. The project will create a thriving natural space with wildflowers and wildlife. Volunteers are advised to wear appropriate footwear, and limited parking is available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book, described as "emotionally exhausting and powerful." The award was presented at the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival, where US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her work, including creating the detective VI Warshawski. Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, praised the strong shortlist and Hilary's book for its fine and tight writing. Hilary's novel, "Someone Else's Skin," addresses domestic violence and honour crime and is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Paretsky was recognized for her 23-year career and her impact on crime fiction, particularly for creating a strong female protagonist and founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old cricketer, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed that there is "unfinished business" with Santner, who had made a promising start before his injury. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, will rejoin Worcestershire after the ICC Trophy in June. He is eager to make up for lost time and contribute significantly. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, ruled it an unlawful killing, noting Pring's inebriation and the car's stolen plates. Pring's family and friends believe he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run, suspecting Ziuzina's involvement due to her actions following his death, including attempting to claim his assets and having an affair. Despite efforts, Ziuzina did not attend the inquest. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, which remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son, Charlie, from Merseyside, urgently needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital for experimental T-Cell Therapy after a failed transplant, as no other treatment options are available in the UK. The family was overwhelmed and grateful when an anonymous donor paid for the treatment. Charlie has been ill since age three and faced a third relapse in April. The donation was confirmed via email from the hospital, allowing treatment to start soon. Charlie's parents expressed immense gratitude for the donor's generosity.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud and Apple's response to enhance security. Apple has introduced an optional two-step verification process that requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device, in addition to the username and password, to access iCloud. This measure aims to prevent unauthorized access, but it remains an opt-in feature. Experts suggest making it the default option. The two-step verification was previously not applied to Apple's backup service, allowing hackers to exploit it using Elcomsoft's software. The software's owner acknowledged that Apple's new security measures are effective. However, concerns remain about the recovery key's potential loss or theft. Another expert emphasized the need for two-factor authentication to be the default setting. Apple plans to encourage stronger security practices among users.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town FC are still pending. The Sun reported that Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league footballer, will become a club director. Billericay Town FC is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week. Additionally, the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of workers at his company's warehouse in Derbyshire, following a BBC investigation. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The letter mentions that Mr. Ashley had invited the committee to meet at the company's Shirebrook base, but he has not agreed to any proposed dates for a public meeting at Westminster. The committee may escalate the issue if he fails to attend. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter but has previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," completed by colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, Ilya Yashin, which accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. The report compiles existing facts from various media sources to highlight the human and economic costs of the conflict. It claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in the pro-Russian rebels' victories in eastern Ukraine, despite Russia's denial of direct involvement. The report includes evidence from volunteer soldiers and details on military spending and operations. However, publishing the report faces challenges due to fear among publishers and the public's mixed reactions. The opposition believes Putin orchestrated the war to boost his popularity, a strategy they admit has been effective. Previous reports by the late Boris Nemtsov on corruption and the Sochi Olympics also failed to incite significant protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire, with a post-mortem revealing he died from head injuries. Two individuals, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield and are in police custody.

The passage discusses the tension between the UK government and the devolved administrations, particularly Wales, regarding the Brexit process. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not being consulted on the Article 50 letter before its publication, highlighting a lack of respect towards devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered, emphasizing the UK government's efforts to act in the interests of the entire UK, including Wales. Prime Minister Theresa May mentioned in the letter to Donald Tusk that there would be consultations on which powers should be devolved post-Brexit, potentially increasing decision-making powers for devolved administrations. However, there are concerns about which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany these powers. The passage also notes skepticism about future funding and hints at further details possibly being revealed in an upcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when attacked and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of fund misuse. The company's board, in a San Francisco court filing, stated they do not expect his return. Charney's lawyer claims the company's statements are false and accuse them of invading Charney's privacy to extort him. The court documents include evidence of inappropriate emails to female employees and racially derogatory remarks by Charney, who is also accused of violating the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board argues that no company would risk hiring Charney due to these issues. Additionally, American Apparel obtained a restraining order to prevent Charney from making negative public statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage details the coverage of a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece previously defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, Greece, but will be missing three players in the upcoming game at the Copper Box, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, excited to play in his hometown, emphasizes the importance of this game for their preparation for EuroBasket 2017. This match is GB's only home game before EuroBasket, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. Following this game, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up. The game will be broadcast from 17:30 to 19:30 BST.

The passage recounts the author's experience during the launch of the iPhone by Steve Jobs. Initially skeptical, the author managed to get a hands-on look at the iPhone for a news piece, which led to some criticism for giving the product undue prominence. Reflecting on the iPhone's impact, the author acknowledges its revolutionary role in transforming technology and daily life, particularly in mobile photography and internet use. The passage concludes by recognizing the iPhone launch as a pivotal moment in the advent of the mobile connected era, despite initial doubts.

The charity confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance, with the most recent case being the death of a seven-month-old cat named Meereen. An RSPCA spokesman stated it was unclear if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. In the past two weeks, four other cats in the area have also died. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described the cat's symptoms and subsequent death after consuming antifreeze. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urged residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely and ensure no antifreeze leaks or spills.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where despite the Syriza government's impending agreement to more austerity and liberalization measures, there are no street protests. Greece's tourism is booming, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals. The lack of protests may be due to anticipation of further concessions by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to secure €86 billion in new credit from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end austerity, and Greece faces severe economic challenges, including bank closures and reduced economic activity. The passage suggests that for the new bailout to succeed, creditors must ease Greece's debt burden significantly.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will make a brief return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy, who reappeared to announce her cancer's return, will be killed off in emotional scenes. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, is returning to reunite the Mitchell family. He expressed his excitement about filming classic episodes and reuniting with his on-screen family. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the significance of Grant's return and the opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden's performances.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recounted the moment they were informed of her death by police, immediately suspecting Dhillon. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice and his stalking behavior. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for previously downplaying the threat to Alice, while Prof. Ruggles acknowledged their underestimation of the danger. In response, they established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The passage discusses the approval and subsequent delay of the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power project in Somerset, primarily financed by French firm EDF with significant Chinese investment. EDF's board approved the funding, but the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, announced a further review, causing uncertainty. Critics cite environmental concerns, escalating costs, and foreign involvement. The project, expected to supply 7% of the UK's electricity, faces financial strain on EDF, leading to internal resignations. The delay has raised concerns about energy supply and climate commitments. The timeline highlights key milestones, including government proposals, construction approvals, and investment agreements.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom a spouse has committed adultery, which family lawyers argue adds unnecessary conflict and complexity. The Ministry of Justice clarifies that there is no obligation to name this person. Lawyer Margaret Heathcote and others express concern that the form's design encourages naming third parties, increasing conflict. The updated form aims to be more user-friendly, but guidance stating it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party may be overlooked. Naming the third party involves them in the court case, potentially causing delays and additional costs. Statistics show adultery was the reason for 12,148 out of over 100,000 divorces in 2015. Lawyer Georgina Hamblin notes that many clients initially want to involve the new partner, but judges disapprove of this. The Ministry of Justice reiterates that naming a third party has always been possible but is not required.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental priorities and commercial forestry in Britain, particularly in Wales. Britain is a major wood importer, and ministers are promoting woodland creation, but Confor, a forestry industry group, warns that significant commercial forest areas have been lost and need replanting. The industry is economically significant, worth over £450m annually to Wales. However, there is a conflict with environmental policies favoring native species and recreational access, which conservationists argue are better for wildlife. The Welsh government seeks a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects, promoting schemes like Glastir to encourage woodland planting. Martin Bishop of Confor criticizes the current system as overly bureaucratic and insufficient to meet timber demand, highlighting a need for increased planting to meet long-term targets.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge near Langloan Primary School. Emergency crews responded to the incident on Bank Street at about 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko awarded Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91-year-old Charles Lewis, who felt honored. Initially, the Foreign Office blocked Russia from honoring these veterans due to rules on foreign medals. The convoys were crucial in aiding Soviet forces against Germany during WWII, enduring severe conditions and heavy losses. The Russian Embassy emphasized the convoys' importance and long-awaited recognition. Despite initial resistance, the British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012, and an exception allowed the Ushakov medals to be awarded in 2013. The Ushakov medal honors sailors for their courage in defending Russia.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant delays and leniency in enforcing community payback sentences, with some offenders completing minimal hours over extended periods. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's 15 recommendations, which include improving organization and ensuring offenders face consequences for non-attendance. The report highlighted both issues and successes, noting that some offenders gained skills and viewed their sentences positively. However, the chief inspector criticized the overall management and delivery, calling for urgent improvements. The Ministry of Justice aims for more effective rehabilitation and is committed to implementing the report's recommendations.

The passage discusses the criticism faced by comedian Russell Brand, who is accused of hypocrisy for advocating economic and political revolution while living in a luxury home. This accusation is frequently directed at him, questioning how a wealthy individual can represent the poor. Brand's vlogs reveal his spacious London home, and during a campaign supporting east London estate residents, he was questioned about his own living situation, which he did not appreciate. Brand has been condemned as a hypocrite before and has responded by acknowledging his wealth and fame, admitting the need for personal and systemic change, and emphasizing that his wealth does not negate the reality of economic disparity and ecological issues. He argues that the focus on his hypocrisy detracts from addressing these significant problems.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, facing criticism from the scientific community for his approach and lack of modesty. Despite this, his work accelerated the field of human genomics. After the human genome project, he focused on creating synthetic life, leading to the development of an organism named Synthia, published in Science. Venter's journey began with a troubled youth, a transformative experience in Vietnam, and a shift from medical practice to research. His innovative approach to gene sequencing led to significant breakthroughs, including the first complete genome of a free-living organism and the formation of Celera Genomics to decode the human genome. His methods and commercial ventures drew both criticism and financial success, allowing him to fund independent research. In 2006, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute, aiming to create synthetic life and explore oceanic microbial genomes. His work, though controversial, aims to revolutionize industries and address environmental issues.

Researchers in England found that 80% of children who ate school lunches tried new foods at school that they hadn't tried at home, and 50% of parents reported their children requested these foods at home. A survey of around 1,000 parents revealed carrots, sweetcorn, and peas as the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, aimed to address concerns from a Mumsnet survey that some parents provided packed lunches due to their children's fussiness.
