Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted in with only seven minutes left in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, suggesting it lowered the standard. Townsend responded by scoring a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit his mistake and praise Townsend. Despite this, Merson couldn't resist another jab at Townsend following the Tottenham-Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by club president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer is completed, Muto will join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane asserts that Chelsea's interest in Muto is unrelated to their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, scoring 16 goals in 37 appearances and earning 11 caps for Japan. Despite being honored by Chelsea's offer, Muto has not yet decided whether to join the club. The potential £4 million deal would make Muto the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics, which are known to fatten farm animals, may also contribute to childhood obesity. The study compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records, revealing that boys are particularly prone to weight gain and slightly increased height after antibiotic use. The study did not prove causation but suggested that antibiotics might kill gut bacteria that help digest food, potentially increasing appetite and food availability for the body. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the importance of careful antibiotic use in infancy due to its potential role in the global childhood obesity epidemic. The overuse of antibiotics is also linked to higher risks of eczema, digestive issues, and the development of antibiotic-resistant infections.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident witnessed by hundreds of tourists and caught on camera. The guard lost his footing, hit his bearskin on the sentry box, and dropped his rifle. He quickly got up, blushing as he realized the crowd had seen his fall. The slip was likely due to the metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident. The Changing of the Guard is a popular event, attracting thousands of tourists daily in the summer and every other day in the winter. Despite their ceremonial role, the guards are fully operational soldiers.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally had over 100 million viewers. A&E networks, including Lifetime and History, will simulcast the new version in 2016. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake, which aims to be "original" and "contemporary" while drawing more from Alex Haley's novel. The production will consult scholars for authenticity. The remake seeks to resonate with both fans of the original and a new generation, amidst a backdrop of significant racial events in recent U.S. history.

Police are investigating claims by Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, alleges he was pinned to a chair and groped by male staff on his first day, leading him to leave the job immediately. He reported the incident last year amid inquiries into historical child sex abuse cover-ups but faced delays before the police were notified. Lawler, now 64, claims he was threatened to keep quiet and has been haunted by the incident for years. The Palace has assured cooperation with the police investigation, which is ongoing.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping in a car, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, they humorously recount their journey to parenthood and reveal a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made to inform distant loved ones about the baby, and its viral success was unexpected for the couple. Jesse is noted to be the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. The couple hinted at possibly making another video after discovering the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in key scenes and has faded over time. The dress was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia in the 1960s. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh, a suit worn by Clark Gable, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland. "Gone With the Wind," based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child fell 10 to 12 feet but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He suffered minor injuries and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. Zoo officials received eyewitness accounts suggesting the child was dangled over the railing. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been enforcing a 30mph limit, was found angled directly at a house's front door. This camera, along with around 300 others in the West Midlands, had been non-operational since March 2013 due to outdated technology. Speed enforcement has since been managed by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. The re-positioning of the camera remains a mystery, but Birmingham City Council is aware and plans to inspect and possibly remove it. The council is developing a pilot for new digital technology at select sites, but the Wellington Road camera is not included. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, expressed his excitement and readiness to participate, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle also expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability, anticipating impressive performances. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their support for Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, which Barcelona narrowly won 85-80. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their division by points difference. Neymar, who recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile, will return to La Liga action with Barcelona against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies. Neymar's sister Rafaella also attended the basketball game with them.

Italy is facing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants might be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. There has been an increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean and subsequent rescues by the Italian Coast Guard. In the first three months of 2015, Italy registered over 10,000 migrant arrivals, with many using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, though he is unsure of the exact reasons behind Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, who had multiple club options after leaving Barcelona, has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities and quick adaptation to the Premier League. Additionally, Wenger dismisses rumors of a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's performance despite challenges.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently ended his Team Sky career, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets available from April 19. Wiggins is also preparing for the 2016 Rio Olympics, targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, struggled but ultimately defeated Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3. Despite this victory, Williams and Alison Riske lost the doubles match to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams admitted the match was an 'eye-opener' and highlighted her need to adjust to clay courts. The US team captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasized the need for harder work to return to the elite group. Williams' doubles loss marred her otherwise perfect Fed Cup record.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club before moving to Porto in 2009. Despite the club's interest, vice president Matias Patanian acknowledges that securing a deal is complicated. Falcao, who has struggled during his loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, has been in good form for Colombia, equaling the national goalscoring record. River Plate, where Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances, are open to his return, with Patanian expressing the club's dream of bringing him back.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from the 2012 series of The X Factor, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop. The partnership, facilitated by the MILES agency, includes a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed her excitement about the collaboration, noting her regular use of the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and the brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are upset after a billboard featuring Torres was erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. The billboard, intended to thank the community for its support, has been deemed disrespectful by Siler's loved ones, who are calling for its removal. Siler was shot after arming himself during a confrontation with Torres, following a vehicle and foot pursuit. Torres is on leave pending the investigation into the shooting. The police association claims no offense was intended by the billboard.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with three militants also killed. The militants, from the group Jaish al Adal, crossed from Pakistan into Iran. Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to capture the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni group, has previously targeted Shiites and claimed responsibility for attacks in Iran, including a deadly one in 2013. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling these militants. Pakistan condemned the recent attack and is investigating, promising to apprehend any militants who fled into its territory.

The passage discusses a recent political exchange in Japan where Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. This response was prompted by a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler-turned-lawmaker known for his colorful career and political stunts. Inoki, who has a history of high-profile activities including a famous fight with Muhammad Ali and diplomatic efforts in Iraq and North Korea, claimed to have seen a UFO himself. The discussion is part of a broader context where Japanese politicians have previously considered the implications of extraterrestrial encounters.

A passenger named Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. He squatted on the toilet rim to avoid sitting on the seat, fearing it was unclean, but the porcelain toilet collapsed, causing injuries. Too embarrassed to shout for help, he called his companions, who found him bleeding and took him to the hospital, where he received several dozen stitches. Initially, Jin Pai admitted to squatting but later told police he was sitting to avoid compensation claims. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public to sit on toilets, not stand on them.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden bathroom camera. The investigation began when the 15-year-old girl found the camera, leading to charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims and had specifically targeted the girl. Police found 41 videos, some showing children showering, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. He is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing set for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series, featured in his book "Daughter and Salary Man," captures unique father-daughter portraits. The images depict daughters standing calmly while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, leap energetically into the air, often with dramatic poses. These photos, taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, aim to show fathers expressing their fun side, contrasting their usual serious demeanor. Despite the lack of detailed background information, the series has garnered significant online interest for its curious and engaging nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the subsequent focus on the start of the county championship season. Attention quickly shifts to Kevin Pietersen, who is seen posing for a Surrey team photo at the KIA Oval, reflecting on his potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was previously axed by Downton in 2014, is now in a jovial mood and interacting with photographers and teammates. His return to Surrey is part of his effort to rejoin the England Test team, with Surrey's campaign beginning on April 19 against Glamorgan. The passage highlights Pietersen's interactions and his determination to make a comeback to international cricket.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired after a poor performance, Ze Maria was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone but was dismissed again following a 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 international caps, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach of the season. Ceahlaul is currently 16th in the standings, six points away from safety, and Ze Maria will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao, who previously played for Atletico Madrid, joined United on a season-long loan but has struggled to perform at his pre-injury level, scoring only four goals. United is unlikely to make his transfer permanent due to the £46 million fee. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played more and participated in the Champions League, despite his dissatisfaction there.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The tall offender, seen in security footage wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till and about $1500 in cash. The incident occurred at the Union St dairy, where the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, who then ran out screaming. The robber threw the cash register to the ground before fleeing with the till drawer. No weapons were used, and the police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially arrested on March 19 for allowing a 15-year-old student to touch her breasts, she was released on bail but suspended from teaching. Shortly after, another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on consecutive nights in January, leading to her second arrest. The incidents were reported by school police, and Granado was released on a $50,000 bail. The school district has placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being on school property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has garnered over 500,000 views online. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, was seen lifeless in the crocodile's mouth. Tim Weston, a New Zealander on holiday, witnessed the incident and described the crocodile holding the dog for hours. The marina is near a crocodile sanctuary, and these reptiles are common in the area, often seen on the resort's golf course. Social media reactions to the video have been largely negative, with users expressing horror and aversion towards crocodiles.

Steve Bruce remains confident that he can keep Hull City in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which has left them fighting to avoid relegation. Initially targeting 10 wins for survival, Hull has only achieved six, and Bruce now hopes that eight or nine wins might suffice. Hull performed well in the first half against Southampton but ultimately lost due to a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a late goal from Graziano Pelle. With six games remaining, including tough matches against top teams, Bruce believes his team can secure the necessary results if they stay positive. Hull's struggles are attributed to long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's win moved them to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman faced his own issues when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty against team rules.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom after allowing pupils to change their exam answers post-exam, which invalidated the school's SATs results. Guffick also altered some answers himself. Following a tip-off, an investigation by the local education authority confirmed the breach of exam rules, leading the Department for Education to annul the school's SATs results for the year. Guffick admitted to the allegations, expressing regret and claiming he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible. Despite his remorse, he was banned from teaching for at least two years, with the option to appeal within 28 days.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time since joining the club in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. Despite his struggles on the pitch, he enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri, whom he married in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year. The couple, who have been dating since 2012, also have a son together. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, frequently shares her modeling photos on Instagram, where she has over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard, now third-choice goalkeeper at United, has been told he can leave the club and was linked to a move to FC Midtjylland, though no agreement was reached.

The glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite expectations of fetching $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee to stimulate bidding. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008. Jackson, who bought them after the stadium's final game, hoped a new generation would enjoy them. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were seen inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Despite the incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline them and emphasized the importance of understanding their roles as elite sportspeople. He aims to move past the issue and focus on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after suspension. Rodgers highlighted the importance of learning from past near-misses in competitions to achieve future success.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil, after returning to London from international duty, shared a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. Ozil played well in Germany's 2-0 win over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier and is preparing for Arsenal's upcoming match against Liverpool. Despite missing Arsenal's last game due to illness, he is expected to play against Liverpool. Rumors of Ozil being in a Berlin nightclub were dismissed by manager Arsene Wenger. Since recovering from injury, Ozil has contributed significantly with four assists and three goals. He feels well-adjusted to English football, appreciating the frequent matches and lack of a winter break.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed satisfaction with manager Luis Enrique, dismissing rumors of his replacement. Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer, is close to winning the La Liga title and has impressed Bartomeu with his performance. Despite speculation, Bartomeu emphasized that Enrique is focused on the team's current goals and has a contract until 2016. Barcelona is in contention for three trophies this season, and Bartomeu highlighted Enrique's dedication, particularly in preparing for recent matches against PSG and Valencia.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a boost after their FA Cup disappointment. With 14 months left on his current deal, negotiations had been ongoing since the season's start, culminating in an agreement for a contract worth around £100,000 per week, extending until 2020. Henderson, 24, follows teammates Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho in securing a contract extension. Having joined Liverpool in 2011 for £16 million, Henderson has shown significant improvement under manager Brendan Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is a candidate to become club captain after Steven Gerrard's departure to LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the season's end, though Liverpool's Chief Executive Ian Ayre expects Sterling to remain at the club long-term.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Although he has struggled to secure the left back position at Chelsea, he remains committed to the club. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly wins against France and Chile. As the Premier League title race intensifies, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging the team to stay focused and win every game. Luis acknowledges the difficulty of the upcoming matches but believes the team is prepared for the challenge.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North during a match. Initially suspended for being 'reckless,' Hughes's red card was rescinded following an outcry and appeal by Wasps. The incident left North unconscious, his third concussion in two months, leading to a recommendation for him to take a month off. Despite graphic footage and some criticism, many defended Hughes, arguing the collision was accidental. The appeal panel, with new evidence, concluded no foul play occurred. Hughes missed a key match but is now cleared to play, though he won't be in the upcoming game against London Welsh.

A fiery sunset in Washington, captured by Seattle native Tim Durkan, was caused by wildfires in southeastern Siberia. These fires, started by farmers burning grass, spread uncontrollably due to strong winds on April 14, destroying numerous villages. The smoke from these fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets are due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing reds and oranges to dominate, especially during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig from St. Louis, Missouri, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen shortly after purchasing it. The car was found and returned to her with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car. Despite the alterations, she is having the car professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor Mick Sexton, who helped locate her car, Schoenig is creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. Schoenig is described by her friend Marlene Trice as vibrant, happy, and someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club uses incentivised contracts to comply with financial fair play rules. After losing to Manchester United, City’s European qualification is uncertain, with the team currently in fourth place. If Liverpool wins their next match, City will be only four points ahead. The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth must win a qualifying round. The squad has £12 million in bonuses at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team’s poor performance, with seven losses since January, jeopardizing their season and potential signings like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18 team defeated Manchester City's Under 18 team 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' match. The game, held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, featured a high number of local English players, with 10 out of 22 being Mancunian. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The match was free to attend and drew nearly 1,000 spectators. United's coach, Paul McGuinness, aimed to simulate a senior match experience for his players. The game was competitive, with notable performances from Marcus Wood for City and Marcus Rashford for United. The result leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough, while City has lost both of their play-off series matches. The match showcased promising young talents who may have future first-team potential.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who earned his 50th cap in a 1-1 draw with Italy, expressed admiration for Buffon and highlighted the inspiration he draws from the 37-year-old. Hart emphasized his desire to continue learning and achieving more caps, aiming to keep performing well for both his club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market, offering delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. This marks a shift for Chipotle, which previously declined third-party delivery collaborations. The Postmates app uses independent contractors for deliveries. Chipotle's popularity is highlighted by visits from presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the 2013 bombings. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, they describe the immense toll on their family, including the death of their 8-year-old son Martin and severe injuries to their daughter Jane. They argue that a death penalty pursuit would prolong their suffering through years of appeals and prefer a life sentence without parole for Tsarnaev. They emphasize their desire to move forward and not have their remaining children endure prolonged reminders of the tragedy. The Richards stress they are speaking only for themselves and seek closure for their family, Boston, and the country.

A mystery billionaire has converted a Boeing 747 into a £400 million luxury home, featuring bedrooms, multiple lounges, and an onboard restaurant. The custom-built jet, which took three years to complete, is designed for the owner and dozens of guests, replacing the usual 600-passenger capacity. The plane includes a large dining room, a lounge, a 'state room,' an 'aeroloft' with eight beds, a master bedroom, a conference room, and an office/guest bedroom. The interior resembles a luxury hotel, with high-end decor and amenities, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. While the launch was successful, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge failed, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. This was SpaceX's second attempt to land a rocket on a drone ship, following a previous failure in January. The goal of these landings is to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This mission marks SpaceX's sixth trip to the ISS and follows a weather-related delay.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The 69-year-old partnered with NBC's Today show to create a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win an 'ultimate wedding'. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will marry on April 23 at the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel stay, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized the chapel's first-class nature, rejecting any impersonators. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Contestants must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a challenging season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Despite recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, Henderson is optimistic about Liverpool's chances, as they are only four points behind City. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored the goals against Newcastle, with Allen acknowledging a controversial penalty decision. The team is focused on continuing their winning form to pressure City in the race for the Champions League.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute following a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to secure the victory. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, while extending Napoli's winless streak to five matches. Security was heightened for the match due to past violence, but no incidents were reported. Despite missing key players, Roma managed to hold off Napoli, who had a potential penalty claim denied and saw several attempts thwarted by De Sanctis.

Doncaster Rovers have had a lackluster season, stuck in mid-table in League One. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town, who had little to play for, ended in a dull 0-0 draw. The match was so uneventful that Doncaster's media team created a very brief 27-second highlight video, featuring just 14 seconds of match action, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes the unique relationship between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid fish. Unlike typical marine pets, this fish enjoys physical interaction with its owner. Giroux captures their interactions on video, showing the fish being gently massaged and stroked by his hand. Initially hesitant, the fish soon returns for more attention, even swimming up Giroux's arm. The fish used to share its tank with two other fish, but they were removed due to bullying. Over time, the fish became more sociable, enjoying daily massages and becoming frustrated if not played with. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, was first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team, highlighting his fiery character and past incidents, such as breaking his wrist by punching a locker and clashing with Marlon Samuels. It emphasizes the importance of channeling his aggression positively and the role of England coach Peter Moores in guiding him. The author appreciates Stokes' unique personality in a sport often criticized for producing unremarkable players. The passage also touches on the potential team selection dilemma involving Stokes and Chris Jordan, advocating for their inclusion to help them develop further. The overall message is to balance Stokes' natural exuberance with controlled aggression to maximize his contributions to the team.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out its 33,000 tickets. Both teams are tied at 11 points in Group B, with Belgium leading due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel, highlighted by Gareth Bale's performance, has raised hopes of qualifying for their first major tournament since 1958. The Football Association of Wales reported high demand for tickets following the win. Despite speculation, the match will not be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules and the team's preference for the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions, England, who won last year by beating Holland on penalties, qualified for this edition with a perfect record. They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes notable players from Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, the latter being called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round qualifiers. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth academy. Patoulidis has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously declined an offer from Barcelona's La Masia academy to focus on his studies. Manchester City have discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the young talent for the future.

A man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, who was found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. The suspect, a 23-year-old man, has been bailed and is required to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan before her death. Santillan, who worked in London, Paris, and Miami, was pronounced dead at the scene by the London Ambulance Service on March 28. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and seeking help from the public to understand the circumstances of her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to confront her long-term friend and housemate, Jamie, over the theft of £207 set aside for her baby's gravestone. Jamie, a convicted burglar, initially denied the theft but was proven guilty by a lie detector test. Dawn was devastated and furious upon learning the truth, especially since Jamie had confessed his love and blamed his girlfriend Carol for the theft in a Facebook message. Dawn expressed her deep sense of betrayal and sorrow, emphasizing the importance of the gravestone for her buried child, Daniel James.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, the ill, and elderly, who were previously captured when ISIS overtook their towns in northern Iraq. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders and the freed Yazidis were sent to Irbil by the Peshmerga forces. The exact reason for the release is unclear. Yazidis, a Kurdish minority with a pre-Islamic religion, have faced severe persecution, including mass killings and enslavement by ISIS. An international coalition responded with humanitarian aid and airstrikes against ISIS. The Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated at 500,000.

Harry Kane, a standout player for Tottenham and the England national team, has had a remarkable season, earning nominations for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. In addition to his on-field success, Kane is featured in a new animation by Copa90 that highlights some of his best goals and celebrations. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', showcases his notable performances, including goals against Chelsea, Arsenal, and on his England debut. The animation has been released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane competes with top players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite a trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work, believes Rodgers should not be judged on one game and acknowledges the challenges with new players not yet settling in. Liverpool is seven points behind fourth place, making Champions League qualification unlikely. Carragher emphasizes the importance of correct signings for future success and hopes Rodgers can lead the team to a trophy and a top-four finish next season. Carragher's community efforts include coaching in deprived Merseyside schools through his 23 Foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security deemed it a risk. The toy, a brightly colored nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was found in his hand luggage. Security officers, described as 'over-zealous' by James's father, Phil, frisked the boy and took the toy. Phil criticized the security measures as 'ludicrous' but complied to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. After their holiday, James received a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized, noting they had offered to mail the toy back, and emphasized that security regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, as set by the government.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, named Rich, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed specific requirements for his ideal partner, including a love for pets, being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fitness, attractiveness, reliability, honesty, loyalty, and good domestic skills. Rich described himself as a 31-year-old with an athletic build, heavily tattooed, and successful, with interests in the outdoors and sports. He offered various benefits to the successful candidate, such as accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership. Rich emphasized that former partners should not apply and assured that all reasonable offers would be considered. Attempts to contact him by Daily Mail Australia were unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke, supported by five former England managers, is advocating for significant changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. He also proposes redefining 'home-grown' to mean players trained in England for three years before age 18. Despite facing opposition from the Premier League, Dyke's proposals aim to address the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level, which the former managers believe is crucial for England's future success in international football. They emphasize the need for opportunities for young talents like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling to ensure England remains competitive on the world stage.

In the latest episode of "Poldark," Demelza Poldark, who was barely showing last week, has given birth to a baby daughter. The episode quickly transitions from the announcement of her pregnancy to her being eight months pregnant and then giving birth, which has drawn comments from fans about the unrealistic timeline. Aidan Turner's character, Ross Poldark, is shown lovingly with his new daughter, solidifying his commitment to Demelza despite their marriage initially being out of duty. Fans have noted the rapid progression of pregnancies in the show, with some humorously commenting on social media about the swift timelines.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused on their own performance and not worry about their relegation rivals as they fight to avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League. Despite being at the bottom of the table, Leicester is just three points from safety after consecutive wins, including a crucial 3-2 victory over West Brom, where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Pearson emphasized the importance of concentrating on their own games and maintaining realistic expectations, noting that while favorable results from other teams are helpful, the primary focus should be on their own efforts.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a record for the longest mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip, which included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests she might be from Mexico, challenging the belief that she is an endangered western gray whale. This finding could imply that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays, prompting a reevaluation of their genetic differentiation.

Residents on Japan's Hokkaido Island experienced a surprising change when 1,000ft of seabed surfaced overnight near Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula. The new land, rising up to 50ft above sea level, is believed to have emerged due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The landmass, measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft in length and 100ft in width, appeared without any noticeable tremors or sounds. Local authorities and researchers, including Yoshinori Yajima, confirmed the phenomenon through aerial surveys. The event is not linked to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of his departure from Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) and expressed his affection for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent conflict with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG and has no plans to leave, even expressing a desire to sign a new contract. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could influence his future at the club.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus and return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus runs until the end of next season, Tevez has reportedly informed the club of his wish to depart this summer. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, confirmed that they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old striker but emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their top scorer, who has netted 17 goals this season, they have accepted his decision and are seeking replacements. Tevez, who began his career at Boca Juniors, has always intended to finish his career there. His international manager, Tata Martino, stated that the move would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore his trousers in the excitement of his team's 6-1 victory over Porto, which secured their place in the semi-finals. Bayern led 5-0 at half-time with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto's initial two-goal lead from their previous 3-1 win in Portugal, they were overwhelmed by Bayern's performance. Guardiola humorously remarked he would need new trousers for the next match.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, Brisbane. The incident involved three vehicles and resulted in several injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were the first to be airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also flown out with arm and abdominal injuries. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped and had to be freed by emergency crews using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway has been closed with diversions in place.

The passage discusses the anticipation surrounding a crucial Premier League match between Arsenal and Chelsea, highlighting Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil's excitement for the game, showcased by his new Apple Watch. Ozil shared his enthusiasm on Instagram, comparing his watch to Michael Knight's from Knight Rider. The passage also mentions Jack Wilshere's return from injury, with club legend Ray Parlour emphasizing Wilshere's potential and the importance of his fitness for Arsenal's future. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six league games left, and Wilshere's fitness remains a key concern for the team.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford on Sunday, despite having sent off three players from these teams this season. City captain Vincent Kompany, who was dismissed by Clattenburg during an international match, is suspended for the upcoming match against Wales. Clattenburg has been accused of favoring United in the past but has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players. The derby is crucial as United recently moved a point above City, adding extra significance to the match. Clattenburg, considered one of the Premier League's top referees, will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as 'a little black puppet on a string' following allegations of domestic violence and revelations of Gordon's criminal past. Katter, who has faced racism himself, sympathizes with Gordon and criticizes the assumption that Gordon would resign, noting that similar federal cases did not lead to resignations. Gordon, who quit the Queensland Labor Party, plans to remain in parliament as an independent, causing political instability. Katter's statement has sparked social media criticism for its terminology, which he defends as a deliberate comment on racial attitudes.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment, Dayna creates enthusiastic dance videos to show that she is just like everyone else, albeit doing things differently. Her videos aim to entertain and encourage people to think before judging those with disabilities. Dayna also engages in motivational speaking at local schools, turning negativity into positivity and demonstrating that she can lead a life similar to any other teenager.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase, is interested in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez would be a significant commercial draw and popular among Orlando supporters, but he is also attracting interest from eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for around £8 million. Additionally, United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has garnered interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

A gang of at least three people set a car on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning after an argument with the driver. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who fled, leaving two passengers in the car. The group then doused the car in gasoline and ignited it. No one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, using surveillance video, and the suspects are still at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these actions, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. Manuel agreed not to seek reinstatement of his license for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances leading to the revocation no longer exist before he can practice again. He also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medications. His practice was located on a residential street in Lamoni.

The passage describes a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in what the U.S. deemed an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The U.S. claims the Russian jet performed aggressive maneuvers at high speed near their aircraft in international airspace north of Poland. Russia, however, stated the U.S. plane was flying towards its border with its transponder off, which the U.S. denies. The U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint. This is not the first such incident; a similar encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk. Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently encounter each other in various regions.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was taken by breaking the car's window and using another vehicle to pull the case free. The theft, which occurred overnight on March 27, also included the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. Evidence such as skid marks and rope pieces were found near the car, and some stolen items were later discovered at a nearby hotel. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and it is unclear if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, allegedly killed his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra. Costa is accused of stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his mental state during the incident. Mullen noted evidence of Costa's fluctuating mood and confusion, supported by triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces at the crime scene. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa might have feigned memory loss, but Mullen disagreed, asserting Costa's long-term mental decline. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as proving his instability could lead to a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley. Barkley, who had not previously taken a penalty, took the 10th-minute kick instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty record. Martinez supported Barkley's decision, stating he was within his rights to take the penalty and praised his responsibility. Despite Barkley's miss, which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, Everton won the game with a goal from Kevin Mirallas. Martinez emphasized the importance of having multiple players capable of taking penalties based on their confidence at the moment.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide, according to Holland America Line. The discovery was made by the cleaning staff at 11:30 a.m. Thursday. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating. The ship, which left Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has successfully led Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced by drawing 2-2 with Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-1 victory in Willemstad. Key to their advancement was a late goal by Charlton Vicento. Curacao will face Cuba next. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has a notable history in World Cup competitions, both as a player and as an assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of survival. He joined Leicester after a successful career at Inter Milan and Real Madrid, where he won numerous trophies. Cambiasso has quickly become a key player for Leicester and is content with his life in the East Midlands, though his future with the club beyond his one-year deal is uncertain.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her two young children due to her refusal to stop drinking and partying. Her mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, is considering this ban after discovering Gemma's use of the legal high MKat and suspecting her of theft. Debbie stepped in to care for the children after social services threatened to take them away, citing Gemma's unfit behavior. Despite Gemma's denial of stealing an iPad, she admits to past thefts from her mother. Debbie, who appeared with Gemma on The Jeremy Kyle Show, is frustrated with her daughter's irresponsible lifestyle and is preparing to prevent her from seeing the children, who call Debbie "mum." Debbie emphasizes that Gemma needs to mature and prioritize her children over her partying habits.

Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored to give his team a 1-0 lead against Manchester United, but the Sky Sports punditry team believed there was a foul in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United's Radamel Falcao, causing him to lose the ball. Cesc Fabregas then picked up the loose ball, leading to Hazard's goal. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness highlighted the use of Terry's elbow, Henry sympathized with Falcao, and Redknapp acknowledged Falcao could have been stronger but still deemed it a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. Michael Barnett filmed the incident and uploaded it to CNN iReport. The fire, caused by a blown rear tire, destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Scott's Bible. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were all safe. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a laser system that converts sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors and semi-conductors. This energy can be transmitted to Earth to enhance solar panel efficiency, potentially making solar power viable in places like Scotland and providing immediate power to disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further trials are planned in Portugal. Unlike fictional space lasers, these will not be powerful enough to cause harm. A similar concept by Tokyo researchers involves using lasers on the ISS to clear space debris, but these too are not weaponizable. Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about the control of such technology.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday. He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and autism, was previously convicted for possessing indecent images of children and had children's items found at his home. Authorities have launched a manhunt and are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

Donald Sterling's former companion, V. Stiviano, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after being sued by Sterling's wife, Shelly Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of exploiting wealthy older men and using the couple's money for luxury items and a duplex. Stiviano argued that the gifts were given willingly by Donald Sterling. The court's decision was celebrated by Shelly Sterling's lawyer, who noted it sets a precedent for recovering such gifts. The case follows Donald Sterling's fall from grace after racist remarks led to his NBA ban and loss of the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer activities and urged the club to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to compete for the Premier League title. Speaking after a goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry specifically questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to the title despite his 14 league goals. Henry highlighted Chelsea's successful signings, such as Thibaut Courtois and Diego Costa, as examples Arsenal should follow. He emphasized the need for a competitive squad to win the league, suggesting that Arsenal's current lineup is insufficient.

A young woman testified in court about the severe impact of years of sexual abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who kept the abuse secret until Van Ryn was caught, expressed fears for her future relationships and revealed her struggles with depression and self-harm. She did not understand the abuse was wrong as a child and has since been scared of people finding out. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is feeling increasingly better as he prepares to return after over a year out due to a serious knee injury. Gnabry, who impressed last season, has not played for the first team since March 2014. Recently, he played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under-21s against Reading, marking his second full game in a week. Gnabry expressed optimism about his recovery and upcoming games.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, tragically died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while attempting to evade a taxi fare. After a night out in Cardiff, Phillips and his friends, lacking sufficient cash, decided to run from the taxi driver. In the dark, Phillips leapt over a fence and unknowingly plunged off the cliff. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker. An inquest concluded his death was accidental, noting he was likely disoriented and unaware of the cliff's danger. Phillips, who worked for Pretty Green and had studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham, was visiting Wales for Christmas and staying with his mother.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays have not received compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit and awarding managers bonuses up to £3,500. Ministers refused blanket refunds for families who paid extra for expedited services or missed trips. The backlog peaked with over half a million passports stuck in the system. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Committee's call for broader compensation was rejected by ministers. Many affected individuals, including those who missed significant trips, received no reimbursement.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The semi-detached property retains original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars. Inside, it boasts a wood-panelled hallway, original bathroom and kitchen, and vintage cupboards. The dated bathroom features a mint green and black color scheme. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the potential renovation costs may deter developers. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth 'Babyface' Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures."

Anne Rice, originally from New Orleans, later lived in Texas and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, facilitating access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended the Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. The band drew influences from various genres and released a self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo album, Everyday Robots, co-produced by Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP), Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The 2007 film "Shooter" features Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit. The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action to thwart a plot to kill the president.
"House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012."

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, all carried out by his followers. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career with a brief TV appearance in 1974, directed by his father. Penn's film debut was in "Taps" (1981), and he gained critical attention in the 1980s with roles in "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" (1982) and several crime dramas. He became a prominent leading actor with "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received further Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), and won Best Actor Oscars for "Mystic River" (2003) and "Milk" (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has held prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he plays in the band Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Additionally, Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

"The Millers" was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running for 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of the second season had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards (1935-1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP called "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

"Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels."

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on 24 July 1783 and died on 17 December 1830. He played a key role in the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under mysterious conditions.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith and became the 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
The passage describes "Marnie" as a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, it is not directed at specific individuals. Advertising is disseminated through various mass media, including traditional media like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as new media like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward. It was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and stayed until he was thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and, in 343 BC, began tutoring Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He was selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft and won a championship and the NBA Finals MVP Award in his rookie season. Johnson won four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. After protests from fellow players, he retired but returned in 1996 to play 32 games before retiring for the final time. In 2009, Ebony magazine named him one of America's most influential black businessmen. He has various business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The band gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I (1566-1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments and laws, James ruled both in personal union and advocated for a single parliament for the two countries. He achieved most of his goals in Scotland but encountered significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000. He also did continuity announcements for Channel 4 until 2011, when he continued narrating Big Brother on Channel 5. Bentley's voice-over work and Geordie accent have made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany, covering 18,413 km², and the sixth most populous, with 4 million residents. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production. It is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and, along with the Saale-Unstrut wine region, one of the only two wine regions in former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, United States. "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing the song "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"**Mohra**" is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of the year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead, but after her death, Raveena Tandon replaced her. The film is also noted for its popular songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure. Additionally, "Hourglass" is the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and making his directorial debut with the 2005 film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang.
"A View to a Kill" (1985) is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and the seventh and final one to feature Roger Moore as the MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, covering most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya, and before that, West Irian or Irian Barat, encompassing all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, but there were unconfirmed rumors that his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6," featuring the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album ("J.Lo") and film ("The Wedding Planner") in the same week. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album "This Is Me... A working animal is typically a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform various tasks. Morse code is a method of transmitting text using on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by skilled listeners without special equipment. Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. From 1960 to 1996, the country endured a bloody civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate. Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the start of the twentieth century, its population was primarily composed of European immigrants.

Homer is the name given by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two central works of ancient Greek literature. "The Thicket" is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has an estimated population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th-most-populous country in the world and the ninth in Asia. It shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand, and is near the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. It is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on developing methods and technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It draws from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control.
